item.title: China | Yuan below expectations after reaching highs against the dollar
item.description: China's central bank yesterday set its reference exchange rate for the yuan below what markets expected, in a sign that Beijing is seeking to halt the currency's recovery against the dollar. According to information released by the People's Bank of China (PBOC, central bank) on its official website, the official exchange rate for yesterday was set at 7.0733 yuan per dollar, 164 'pips' (one hundredth of 1 percent, a measure used in exchange rate analyses) below the most widespread forecasts among investors and analysts. The decision, highlights the Bloomberg agency, represents the biggest difference between market expectations and the rate finally fixed by the BPC since February 2022. The exchange rate fixed by the BPC is fundamental for the quotation of the “onshore” rate — negotiated in national markets — of the yuan, since it can only deviate within a maximum daily range of 2 percent, both when it appreciates and when it depreciates. Given the optimism that followed the trade truce between China and the United States, followed by the announcement of the possible visit of US President Donald Trump to the Asian country next year, the yuan has been approaching the psychological barrier of 7 units per dollar, and its value in the markets is on track to reach the highest levels since 2020. Part of the appreciation of the yuan in relation to the dollar is also due to fears, reflected in the US currency, regarding the budgetary policy of the United States, as well as forecasts of a reduction in interest rates by the Federal Reserve (Fed). "The PBOC has been prioritizing exchange rate stability, so it is not surprising (…) that they are slowing down the pace of increases. We do not expect the level of 7 units [per dollar] to be put to the test for the rest of the year, but it will probably be surpassed at some point next year", said Lynn Song, ING's chief economist for China, cited by Bloomberg.

item.title: Taxis | Request more services per application
item.description: The Association of Automobile Traders and Workers of Macau considers that Macau should have mobile phone applications to hail taxis similar to Didi or Uber, calling on the Government to bring this service to the territory when launching the public consultation to review the regulations on passenger transport in Taxis. Speaking to the newspaper Ou Mun, the president of the association, Leng Sai Vai, praised the importance of this type of service, stressing that currently taxi drivers can only have customers in nearby areas, such as casinos or border posts, with customers in areas further away from stopping points having difficulty calling a vehicle. The person in charge believes that creating these applications in Macau can bring more customers, increasing the effectiveness of the service and providing greater convenience to passengers.

item.title: Floods | DSAMA publishes Tide Table for 2026
item.description: The Directorate of Services for Maritime and Water Affairs (DSAMA) has just released the Tide Table for next year, stating, in a statement, that the “pioneering introduction of hourly tide height data” is being made, which can help combat floods. In this way, “the prediction of the tide height at each hour is added, in addition to the data on the height of high tides and low tides each day, allowing the maritime sector and the general public to access in a more practical way the predictions of hourly variations in tides”. Tidal data collection began in 1925, and Macau's annual tide tables have been produced since 1960. Tide predictions are obtained from the analysis of tide level data, measured and permanently recorded at the Porto Interior Tide Station. Tide forecast data is made available in real time to meteorological services for reference, allowing the calculation of tidal heights resulting from the combination of astronomical tides and the effects of “Stormsurge”.

item.title: AMAGAO | “Meet You There” features works by Alexandre Marreiros and Nyoman Suarnata
item.description: Architect and artist Alexandre Marreiros is back at exhibitions, but this time he is not alone. In “Meet You There”, opened today at the AMAGAO gallery, Marreiros joins his friend Nyoman Suarnata for an exhibition that reflects “territories of adjustable perception”, with concepts shaped by “collaboration, dialogue and imagination” The AMAGAO gallery, a project by Lina Ramadas and Vítor Hugo Marreiros, hosts a new exhibition today. “Meet You There” begins to receive its first visitors at 6:30 pm, featuring works by two artists who decided to join forces: Alexandre Marreiros, who usually wanders between arts and architecture, and Nyoman Suarnata. In the curatorial text about this exhibition, it is stated that “Meet You There” is not just “a point on the map”, but rather “a conceptual territory shaped by collaboration, dialogue and imagination”, where the two artists “transform canvas and paper into a shared space where perception is fluid and the narrative pulses like a living organism”. This “creative encounter” brings a new “place where visual language becomes an instrument of investigation”, with works with “overlapping compositions, fragmented symbols and constantly shifting perspectives”, where “artists build a territory that resists fixed meaning”. And what elements live in this new territory full of concepts and conceptions? “Social, personal and environmental concerns”, which then “metamorphose into characters, symbols and even superheroes”. "These are not figures that save, but that reveal. They are incarnations of urgency, empathy and resistance, challenging the viewer to reflect: what does it mean to care? Imagine? Act?", the same text asks. This exhibition invites you “to participate in a space where art is not static, but generative; where dialogue is not linear, but stratified; and where imagination is a form of engagement and participation”. Studio work Speaking to HM about the exhibition, Alexandre Marreiros talks about an exhibition created by two friends, with much of the work carried out in Macau, together, in a permanent collaboration. This was due to “several trips that Nyoman made to Macau, namely to my studio, where he was free to choose any of my works”. "There was always an interesting construction, a long process, first for Nyoman to free himself and choose a work of mine without limitations. After a day of work I responded to his interventions. At first it was a curious thing, because he had great respect and almost didn't touch the parts he had already painted and I didn't touch his things either, but we felt that there was a kind of limit, something we didn't want. There was a very interesting exercise in liberation, in which I opened the doors of my studio, I gave him the works that He had to be able to choose and intervene in them, and then I would respond.” Thus, 34 works emerged in around two years of joint work, in which the artistic skills of both came into contact. "If we look back, we see that I always have a graphic resource and also the word in my works. Nyoman also has that register, something perhaps more handwritten, and I had other techniques, be it screen printing, lithography or drawing, I used them a lot to transport the word to my works." Alexandre Marreiros assumes that “in some way, there is always a character” in his works, namely “poets and philosophers”, more specifically “there is always a predominant character in my work, which is Luís de Camões”; while Nyoman “has a universe of characters that can be assimilated, or not, in a critical way, or that can be considered superheroes or a human being with supernatural powers”. “Meet You There” is, therefore, the result of a permanent collaboration, in which one artist worked on the other’s works in their absence, in which there were “few opportunities, perhaps 10 or 20 percent, in which we could both participate directly in the work”. “It's something you feel in the work, which is honest, in the sense that there is a universe of communion, universality and trust, of two very different people who meet, respect and admire each other”, said Marreiros. Contemporary themes In these works there is satire “of the times in which we live”, namely “in a series of works, the first, and which are very much the representation of what Nyoman sees in Macau”. There is then another series “with his superheroes and mine, which are always the writers, philosophers and human beings who, in some way, left their mark on this passage that is life”. There are also other works “a little more linked to Macau, namely to the world of casinos”. “I actively and directly participate in this Macau identity and industry and, therefore, it is natural that this universe appears in my work and there are interventions and reinterpretations by Nyoman.” Macau has always been, for the two artists, “a meeting and work point”, with this project being “a liberation” for Alexandre Marreiros, in the sense that he opened the door of his studio to Nyoman's interventions. It is “an exhibition that talks about globalization, relationships of trust, cultural, artistic and intellectual differences that can coexist in the same territory”. There are satirical messages “that reveal some concerns of the two artists in the context in which they live and in the context in which they operate globally”. “Meet You There” is, for Alexandre Marreiros, “an exposure of our time and context, and revealing that differences can coexist and create beautiful dialogues and narratives, which are also different”.

item.title: GP | Unanimity regarding “Super Pole” in GT
item.description: The International Automobile Federation (FIA) should continue to focus on the “Super Pole” system for the ninth FIA GT World Cup, if this race is once again included in the program of the 73rd Macau Grand Prix next year For the first time, in last November's edition, the ten fastest in Qualifying 1 had 20 minutes to prepare for the first “Super Pole” in the history of the FIA ​​GT World Cup, in which, in reverse order of times, each driver entered the track alone for one out lap, two timed laps and one return lap, with one-minute intervals between competitors and the possibility of using a new set of tires. The best time obtained between the two timed laps determined Qualification 2 “Super Pole”, which defined the starting grid for the Classified Race. Following the success of this initiative, the international federation intends to continue applying it in the Macau GT Cup – FIA GT World Cup, having even produced a promotional video to confirm this. Lutz Leif Linden, President of the GT Commission and the FIA ​​Constructors' Commission, admits that this is something “very exciting for the spectators as well as the drivers”. Present in Macau during the Grand Prix, the influential Stéphane Ratel, CEO of SRO Motorsports Group, co-organizer of the Macau GT Cup – FIA GT World Cup, also agrees with the measure, highlighting that it represents "an additional challenge and one that works. At SRO we do this on a global level. In the biggest events, like the 24 Hours of Spa, we have a 'Super Pole', and it is something we like." Riders and brands agree Drivers and brands were equally impressed with this first experience on the territory's streets. “Macau is already special and I think that, with this format, we had something even more special”, recalled Antonio Fuoco, the driver who gave Ferrari its first in Macau since 1995. Ferdinando Cannizzo, head of Ferrari's Competizioni GT, reinforces the idea, highlighting the technical advantage when the challenge comes down to the driver and the circuit, without external interference. “Without cars, without traffic, you can really focus on your strengths and try to maximize the car’s performance”, said the Cavallino Rampante brand representative. This qualification system, an important moment of the weekend given the difficulty of overtaking on the Guia Circuit, also adds an element of uncertainty and elevates the spectacle. Stefan Gugger, responsible for the development of Lamborghini's competition cars, said that, in his opinion, "it's an improvement for our fans. We can really see the performance of the driver and the car, which also represents a good challenge for the team." Porsche, one of the brands that most advocated the mandatory introduction of expensive torque sensors in this race, was also one of the main drivers of the “Super Pole”. “I believe the new format is a real step forward,” said Thomas Laudenbach, Vice President of Porsche Motorsport. "It allows the drivers to have clean laps. It's a great step in the right direction, maybe with some tuning, but overall for me it's positive. I hope they maintain this format because it's fantastic." Meanwhile, the date of the 2026 edition of the Macau Grand Prix is ​​expected to be confirmed next week, during the FIA ​​World Council, which will take place before the FIA ​​awards ceremony for 2025, in the city of Tashkent, Uzbekistan.

item.title: IAM | Dogs appear dead again in Coloane
item.description: An internet user shared photographs of three dead dogs on Facebook and reported the presence of IAM employees carelessly spreading rat poison. The IAM says that autopsies revealed systemic hemorrhagic lesions and that death from poisoning is “extremely low”. The case was referred to the police It happened again. On Wednesday, photographs of dead dogs were published on Facebook. The author, who suspected death by poisoning, says he saw employees from the Institute for Municipal Affairs (IAM) and a company hired by the public entity spreading rat poison in an area, in Coloane, where a dead dog was found. According to the publication, the internet user approached IAM and cleaning company employees criticizing the method of applying the poison in violation of established guidelines, which would be exposed on the side of the road, within reach of people and domestic animals. In response, the complainant states that he was told that everything was fine, and they continued to deposit the poison despite the citizen's protests. On Wednesday night, the IAM issued a statement addressing the issue, stating that it had received “successive reports from citizens about the discovery of three dog corpses in three adjacent locations in Coloane”, starting last Saturday. Stating that it is “highly attentive to the incident”, the IAM indicates that it immediately deployed personnel to monitor the cases in the locations in question. "After the autopsy of the corpses and respective analysis, it was found that the three dogs in question had systemic hemorrhagic lesions. The Institute has already reported the case to the police, awaiting further investigation." Carbon paper Regarding the suspicion of poison ingestion by dogs, the IAM highlighted that the product currently used “contains a bitter agent, specifically designed for rats due to their lack of vomiting reflex”. "For animals with a vomiting system, including cats and dogs, accidental ingestion causes a vomiting reaction, making swallowing difficult. Therefore, the probability of poisoning through accidental ingestion is extremely low. Furthermore, the dose of bait placed by IAM workers each time is specifically calculated for the small size of rats," added the public entity. In the Facebook post, the internet user published a photograph where you can see a pile of reddish colored sprinkles. The institute led by Chao Wai Ieng also indicated that the poison is placed in fixed and locked boxes, or in rat holes, remaining hidden and without easy contact by people or animals. A statement completely contradictory to the report of the internet user who reported the situation. At the beginning of May, a similar case also occurred in Taipa with three dead dogs and similar suspicions. At the time, the IAM issued a statement similar to the one released on Wednesday night.

item.title: HIV | Association warns of increasing trends
item.description: Kelvin Lei, project supervisor at the Macao AIDS Care Association, warns of the complexity of the greater number of HIV cases in the non-resident population and regrets that the stigma surrounding the virus and the disease is still a reality in the territory The Macao AIDS Care Association speaks of a scenario of complexity given the growing number of new HIV cases among non-residents. In an interview with HM, Kelvin Lei, the association's project supervisor, describes that “the trend observed among non-residents is complex and reflects structural factors, and not just individual behavior”. These factors are “Macau’s status as an international hub, which means a constant flow of people, including visitors, immigrant workers and students from around the world”, who “may have different attitudes towards high-risk sexual behavior due to their cultural diversity and academic background”. For Kelvin Lei, “greater attention to testing and detecting cases among non-residents can lead to more diagnoses”, and “barriers [in access] to services” persist, particularly due to “linguistic differences, limited knowledge of local health rights, concerns about confidentiality or work schedules that conflict with opening hours”. “The fear of stigma or job loss” still remains, scenarios that can be “a significant impediment to seeking tests or health care”. There are also “socio-economic factors” that explain the growth in cases. Data from the Health Services in November speak of a growing trend in cases: between January and September this year, 28 new cases of HIV infection were registered, 14 of which were among residents and 14 among non-residents. Last year, there was no reference to non-residents being infected. In comparison, between January and September last year, nine cases had been confirmed among residents, meaning that throughout this year there has been a 55.6 percent increase in new cases detected. Important role The conversation with Kelvin Lei arose regarding the holding, this weekend, of the 8th Forum on AIDS in Beijing, Hong Kong, Macau and Taiwan, taking place in Lisbon Macau, in Cotai. In 2016, Macau had organized another edition of this event. For Kelvin Lei, the repetition of Macau as a host location “has a profound meaning” for the association, as it “reaffirms the active and committed role” of the territory “as a vital bridge in the regional partnership between Beijing, Hong Kong and Taiwan in the fight against HIV/AIDS”. “Although Macau’s prevalence [of new cases] remains relatively low, we face distinct challenges, including a mobile population and the need for sustained and targeted prevention,” he said. “The misconception that HIV only affects specific groups, such as men who have sex with men, as is the case globally” also persists in the territory. This is a “harmful idea, because it creates a false sense of security in other populations and worsens stigma”. Focus on the individual Regarding stigma, Kelvin Lei draws attention to the fact that, “in compact communities like Macau and Hong Kong”, there is “a fear of social disclosure within close-knit networks”. It is up to the Executive to incorporate another type of discourse into its policies, he suggested. "We recognize and appreciate the SAR Government's commitment and resource allocation to prevention and treatment, with the clinical infrastructure providing essential antiretroviral therapy. The doctor-patient ratio in this specific area is managed. The discourse has progressively shifted towards a scientific and public health framework. However, the next frontier is to truly integrate the fight against stigma into official discourse and systemic practice." The supervisor speaks of the need for public defense of the “U=U” concept, that is, “undetectable – non-transmissible”, in addition to the need to “promote person-centered care that looks at the individual, and not just the virus”. Kelvin Lei also advises “promoting the standardization of tests for everyone and guaranteeing non-discriminatory policies in all contexts”. Therefore, holding the Forum this weekend brings a dialogue “with representatives from all regions, including the Government, which is a positive step towards aligning our scientific capabilities, with the necessary social support, to end the epidemic”. It is also intended to analyze “innovative strategies, such as long-term prevention and artificial intelligence applications that we are discussing, and a spirit of solidarity”. The AIDS Care Association in Macau sees itself as “one of the main associations in HIV prevention in Macau”, facing “non-medical challenges”, such as “internalized and social stigma”, which “can lead to profound loneliness and mental health problems”. It is also necessary to “guarantee continuity of care”, with “holistic needs” on the part of patients, such as medication, “psychological counseling, support to reveal the condition to family or employers and, sometimes, nutritional or financial assistance”. This association therefore provides a series of support in this regard.

item.title: APAVT | Macau is international “Preferred Destination” in 2026
item.description: The Portuguese Association of Travel and Tourism Agencies once again chose Macau as the association's Preferred Destination in 2026, which will allow for reinforced cooperation. Helena de Senna Fernandes praised the continuation of the good work resulting from the partnership with the Portuguese association "Macau and the Portuguese Association of Travel and Tourism Agencies (APAVT) decided that they should not stop. That is why I convey to you with great joy that we have decided, Macau and APAVT, that Macau will be APAVT's preferred international destination throughout 2026", stated the president of APAVT, Pedro Costa Ferreira in the territory. The 50th APAVT National Congress, which has been taking place since Tuesday in Macau, ended yesterday, and was attended by more than a thousand professionals, a record number, to debate the future of the tourism sector. Macau hosted for the sixth time what is considered the largest congress in the Portuguese tourism sector. "I can't be happier. You know my status in my last term. I'm fulfilling a dream, which is to return to Macau and work with Macau again. (…) The Congress has been, in my opinion, memorable from the point of view of the themes, but it has also been memorable from the point of view of the number, it is the biggest ever, and it has been memorable from the point of view of reception capacity", reinforced Pedro Costa Ferreira. APAVT's Preferred Destination is a “very broad” program, which has two fundamental parts, communication and marketing, and which, in this way, helps the chosen destination to promote itself. “It means that in all our presences, we will have Macau with us and, therefore, we have this communication”, added the president of the association, remembering that in this way a relationship that has existed for many years is reinforced. Old friends “The return of Congress to our city this year and the designation of Macau, along with China, as a Preferred Destination for 2026, paves the way for us to continue working well”, said the director of Tourism Services, Helena de Senna Fernandes. The main new feature of Destino Preferido in 2026 will be the launch of an 'e-learning' program about Macau for travel agents from Germany, Finland and the Netherlands, just like the program that was launched in Portugal in 2024. The 'e-learning' will be developed by APAVT and Macau Tourism, in collaboration with the European Confederation of Associations of Travel Agencies and Tour Operators (European Confederation of Travel Agents’ and Tour Operators’ Associations [ECTAA]). Pedro Costa Ferreira also recalled that this congress has several “special meanings”, firstly “because it is the sixth” in Macau and because it was chosen “to conclude the celebration of the 75th anniversary” of the association. APAVT says it has accredited 1,039 congressmen from 172 different flights, congressmen who “will now visit several provinces in China in collaboration with Macau Tourism”.

item.title: Work | Two-thirds rest only 1 or 1.5 days a week
item.description: A FAOM survey revealed that around 60 percent of workers did not receive a salary update this year and two thirds did not have a two-day weekly rest. Leong Sun Iok wants the Government to give clear guidance to companies to prioritize hiring residents and set a minimum quota for locals Frozen wages, work overload, financial insecurity and unfair competition with very low wages from non-residents were the main concerns revealed by around 2,000 workers who responded to a survey on working conditions in 2025. The work, presented yesterday, was carried out by the Macau Workers' Associations (FAOM). For 60 percent of those interviewed, there were no salary increases this year, while 10 percent even had salary cuts. Furthermore, close to two-thirds of workers complained of an excessive workload, with their weekly rest period reduced to one day or one and a half days. Another situation that disrupts the balance between life and work is technological access that allows work tasks to be transferred to free time and home. This situation once again became the target of complaints from workers, leading FAOM officials to ask the Government to clearly define the parameters of the “right to be offline”. To achieve this, workers must be entitled to overtime compensation, or shift work wages. In addition to these problems, there were frequent reports of a lack of stability and financial “cushion”, causing feelings of insecurity regarding the future. The bogeyman Echoing one of FAOM's political slogans, interviewees consider that labor policies do not effectively prioritize local people in access to employment. As such, 63 percent of respondents revealed a lack of clarity in the protection measures for resident workers. At this point, deputy Leong Sun Iok, stated that “although current laws already define the priority of local residents, the Government has never outlined clear requirements for companies in relation to human resources hiring practices”. The result is a lack of effectiveness in achieving the priority. One solution, pointed out by the deputy, would be the firm application of quotas or minimum proportion of residents in the human resources of each company, as happens with management positions in gaming concessionaires. Leong Sun Iok believes that in this way, employers would be “incentivized” to train local employees. The excessively low wages of non-resident workers, and the resulting unfair competition caused by the salary gap, was highlighted by 60 percent of respondents. Leong Sun Iok argues that the Government should refuse requests to hire non-residents when the salaries proposed by employers are too low.

item.title: Festival of short films and animations to see in the Capitol
item.description: Another edition of the Macau International Short Film Festival has been taking place since Tuesday, promoted by Creative Macau. The sessions take place daily at the Capitol Theater, in the center of Macau, and the awards for the best films, in different categories, will be awarded on the 12th of this month. Starting at 8:30 pm, this Wednesday, the winning films for “Best Film of the Festival”, “Best Fiction”, “Best Documentary” and “Best Animation” will be announced. Today's sessions start at 5pm and feature animated films, namely “Tape”, by Wing Ki Hui; “Fox Box”, by Ao Ka Meng and Wu Hua Lin, from Macau; and “GARU Y PONKI”, by Cristhian Jallier, from Colombia. item.title: Japan bond yields rise to highest level since 2007
item.description: The yield on Japanese 10-year debt reached 1.91 percent yesterday, the highest level since July 2007, due to expectations that the Bank of Japan (BoJ) will raise interest rates. Japan's central bank governor, Kazuo Ueda, sparked speculation on Monday about a possible rate hike, when he suggested in a speech before business leaders that economic conditions are ripe for continuing with the normalization of monetary policy, which the organization suspended in January to assess the impact of new United States tariffs. Without anticipating the outcome of the BoJ's next monetary policy meeting in the middle of this month, Ueda said that “appropriately adjusting the level of monetary easing, neither too late nor too early, is necessary to smoothly achieve the objective of price stability, while ensuring the stability of financial and capital markets.” The words caused sharp falls on the Tokyo Stock Exchange and debt securities, which had already reached highs since the 2008 financial crisis due to concerns about the archipelago's fiscal health, soared. They also happened after the announcement by the new Japanese Executive of Prime Minister Sanae Takaichi, last Thursday, of the project for the expected supplementary budget for 2025, valued at 18.3 billion yen (more than 100 billion euros), which will be financed largely with the issuance of State bonds, and intended above all for an ambitious stimulus package. Central precautions The BoJ is, by far, the largest investor in bonds of the most indebted country among the most advanced economies, whose yield is the barometer par excellence of long-term rates. The central bank has kept benchmark interest rates at 0.5 percent for the past six monetary policy meetings, since a 25 basis point increase in January. The last meeting of the year generated great expectations, after the change of government in Japan, in October, but the BoJ maintained a cautious stance, before knowing the financial position of the new prime minister – who was critical in relation to the rise in interest rates – and also taking a stabilized view on tariff negotiations with the United States, Japan's second largest trading partner, after China.

item.title: DSAT | Survey reveals that almost half of trips are made on foot
item.description: A study carried out by the Directorate of Services for Traffic Affairs (DSAT), relating to 2024, revealed that, among the different modes of travel, walking continues to record the highest proportion, with around 46.5 percent, similar to the 2019 record. However, the proportion falls by 3.2 percent compared to 2009. It is important to note that the survey is carried out every five years. The second most used means of movement in the city is once again the public bus, despite a drop of one percentage point to 20.9 percent last year. Regarding the use of private passenger cars, DSAT reported a slight increase of 0.8 percent between 2024 and 2019, for a total of 15.5 percent. The percentage varies greatly depending on the area of ​​residence, with Coloane, naturally, being the most suitable area for traveling by car or motorcycle. The survey also reveals that motorcycle travel fell slightly between 2019 and last year, with 11.3 percent of the population being the preferred transport.

item.title: Ana Cristina Alves
item.description:
By Ana Cristina Alves, Assistant Researcher and Coordinator of the Educational Service of the Macau Scientific and Cultural Center1 The Taoist philosophy of the beginnings, that of Laozi and the Book of Way and Virtue (《道德经/經》), will choose the water of the ocean and the sea as the privileged image of the Tao (道 Dào), that which cannot be said, without form, on which the universe itself and the ten thousand beings (万物 wânwù) that inhabit it depend, as well as the first principles of existence, the void (無/无 wú), the masculine yang (陽/阳 yáng) and the feminine yin (阴/隂yīn). This choice of an indigenous Chinese philosophy finds its echo in popular language and philosophy, for example in expressions such as “enormous capacity” (海量Hǎiliàng), which can have both an affective and social interpretation of portentous generosity or magnanimity, as well as a physical and concrete one, applying to someone who can ingest large quantities of alcohol. The sea is also linked to the word good and constant, for example in the “oath of eternal love as energetic as the sea and firm as the mountain”, where mountain lends added firmness to the promise (海誓山盟 or 山盟海誓Hǎishì-Shānméng or Shānméng-Hǎishì). The ocean, the sea, but also the great rivers are made up of generous water, both in popular and erudite Taoist philosophy. Here water is the figurative model of the Tao, as read in the Book of Way and Virtue and in the best sinology, which is why we recommend additional reading of Alan Watts Tao: The Watercourse Way. It is worth paying special attention to the chapters in which water appears as the closest representation of the Tao in the Book of Way and Virtue, namely: chapters 8, 14, 34, 66 and 78. In chapter 8 we are informed that the Tao is the supreme good “like water” (上善如水) (Abreu, 2014, 43), but it is not water itself. Therefore, it will be due to the similarity of functions that both are compared. Now water is generous, granting life to all beings, without establishing any distinction between them, its gift reaches even those that no one likes and I am thinking, for example, of parasites. It remains close to the earth to fertilize it, it is deep, simple, true, fair and correct and very timely, when it washes and cleans at the right time. This is also the case with the Tao. In the first verses of chapter XIV, regarding the Tao, an aquatic image appears again:
You look and you don't see, It's called Indistinct. You listen and you don't hear, It's called Silent. Touch and don't get caught, It's called Subtle. This trio is not decipherable For it merges into a unity 2 (Ribeiro, 2004, 32-33) And a little later we are told that he is nameless and uninterrupted (繩繩不可名) (Ibidem) The Tao is like an ocean, an uninterrupted and inexhaustible unity in which someone easily imagines themselves swimming in water that is neither too bright nor too dark, as would happen to Michael Saso in his 14th meditation on the Tao, in A Taoist Cookbook. with Meditations from the Laozi DaodeJing, which he called “Nadar no Tao” (Saso, 1994,47), a meditation that he accompanied by a recipe for spinach, soy paste and sesame, since the wise man is the one who “empties the mind and fills the belly” (虛其心實其復) (Ribeiro, 2004, 10-11), here one feels how the author is immersed in the great Tao, following with the current. Water can also be represented in a large river, as in chapter 34: The great Tao floods like a river, To the left, to the right, Ten thousand beings depend on him. （大道泛兮/其可左右/万物恃之而生） (Abreu, 2013, 94-95) In the same chapter we are told that the Tao not only gives life but nourishes and feeds, being an essential shelter in the return to the origins, not for death, but for eternal life diluted in the great unity, being therefore great, as big as the sea, or rather the great sea, which is the ocean. Whoever wants to be as it should be in existence or even correctly govern the world, must follow the model of the water in rivers and seas, as we read in chapter 66: Rivers and seas are greater than a hundred valleys Because they remain below them, and so they are princes, dominating waterfalls and streams. (江海所以能为百谷王者/以其善下之/故能为百故王)3 (Abreu,2013, 158-159) The wise man's behavior is distinguished by its malleability and spontaneity. He does not impose himself, which is why he is respected by everyone, only he should then govern, because he acts naturally, without oppressing, without hurting, letting everyone follow their course as freely as possible, as is reiterated in chapter 78: Nothing in the world is more malleable and flexible as for water, but in attacking what is hard and rigid nothing can surpass it and there is nothing to replace it. (天下莫柔弱於水/而攻堅強者莫之能先) (Ribeiro, 2004 160-161) Laozi's Taoist water is among the Five Chinese Elements (Water, Wood, Fire, Earth, Metal) the one that evokes great oceanic unity, source of life for everything that exists, but also of death, or rather, of return to origins and eternal life, when this image represents the philosophical principle Tao. And if water, fresh and salty, is the supreme good of the world, the Tao is the origin, the supreme good, including of Heaven. As a root or mysterious female (chap 6) it is the root of the cosmos as we know and experience it. He is a source of spiritual and material life, but so is water, since his model must be followed in all circumstances, from the material source of beings to complex human conduct. People who act correctly, and especially Taoist sages and saints, are aware of the physical and concrete model of water that helps them practice another invisible one, that of Tao. They will then be malleable and adaptable, capable of nourishing themselves from the inside and giving life to any form on the outside. You will know how to transform yourself to better nourish and vivify. The Taoist oceanic model differs from the one that inspired the Portuguese throughout history, who looked to the sea as their ocean. Taoist water is not challenging nor does it call for conquest, it does not have cables of storm or hope to bend, it does not require weapons or boats, nor maps, nor nautical instruments. It is the dominant, conquering element within all beings, who will adapt to this most malleable element, without needing to develop their inventive spirit. The philosophy it leads to does not ask for vigilance or a critical spirit, but adaptation to the world as it is and generosity to accept it with a minimum of suffering and a maximum of joy. item.title: Julie Oyang
item.description: Interview with James Yanzhao Xing, Chinese private collector living in Xi'an, specializing in Ancient Jade (Archaic Jade) Four years ago, in 2021, James inherited more than 300 pieces of antiques from his elderly father. The family heritage dates back to the Song dynasty (10th-13th centuries) and the collection includes exquisite jade items, porcelain, bronze wares, incense burners and high-value jewelry from various periods. During the turbulent war years, these treasures were buried in a hole in the backyard for decades. Now, through their interdisciplinary curatorial project, they are about to enter a dynamic dialogue with the worlds of fashion, art and sport. Joy: Como se sentiu quando recebeu a herança familiar? I was completely surprised! My brothers and I had no idea that our family had such things. We were ignorant about our family history. Joy: Tell me about your family history. James: Our original surname was Zhao and we belonged to the imperial family of the Song dynasty. Our roots are in the heart of Chinese civilization. A história chinesa tem sido complicada e turbulenta e a minha família não conseguiu preservar os detalhes dos nossos altos e baixos específicos. Tudo o que sei é que, em 1931, para fugir da ocupação japonesa, a minha avó levou o meu pai e outros membros da família e, juntos, caminharam até Chongqing, no sul. O meu pai ainda era um menino. Para sobreviver e cuidar melhor do filho e da família, a minha avó decidiu casar-se novamente com um clã local chamado Xing. The Xing family accepted the proposal, as long as my grandmother paid them 300 taels of silver, a significant amount in wartime China. Foi assim que mudámos o nosso apelido imperial Zhao para Xing. Depois de se casar novamente, a minha avó pediu ao meu pai para cavar um buraco no quintal. That's where the family heirloom was stored, until my father decided to pass it on to me. My father didn't want to divide the collection between my brothers, as he knew I was the only one who could appreciate its true value. To repay my father's appreciation for me, I immediately gave my private collection a name: Jade Ambience, 琼华幸境 in Chinese. Joy: Why that name? James: I feel like I've always been lucky in life, like I've always been protected by some supernatural force with which I could cure strange illnesses and save people. You know, I love helping people and I can't stand seeing sadness and injustice in the world. Since he was a child, he saved lives during the annual floods of the Yangtze River in Chongqing. I didn't fear for my own life, because I knew I was protected. Will it be a gift? I would like to believe so. I even abandoned my career as a successful businessman and decided I wanted to be a soldier, so I could actually contribute to my country instead of earning a lot of money. I even turned down an opportunity to go to the USA and run a company there. That was in 1989. My experiences in the army made me stronger, both physically and mentally. I value life's experiences because they make me understand the human world better and give me positive energy to appreciate each day. In some inexplicable way, I attribute all of this to the jade items in my collection (laughs). JOy: In fact, Chinese people believe that jade stone radiates positive energy. Since ancient times, jade has been associated with protective power, healing power and immortality. What is the true value of your collection, in your opinion? As I said, jade has a very special place in Chinese culture. Jade symbolizes moral integrity and virtue, which is the stone's central symbolic value. Confucianism inextricably linked jade to the ideal of the “exemplary person” (junzi 君子), who should embody the virtues reflected in the physical qualities of jade, including benevolence, righteousness, wisdom, courage (“It is better to be a broken jade than an intact tile”) and purity. Jade served as a material expression of authority and was made into ritual objects used to communicate with divine forces and symbolized imperial power—most notably through the legendary Imperial Seal made of jade. For ordinary Chinese people, jade offers protection and good luck and has long been considered a talisman against evil forces. Jade carvings also carry auspicious meanings: bats for blessings, peaches for longevity, and fish for abundance. In ancient belief systems, jade was believed to preserve the body and soul after death. This concept found its ultimate expression in the jade burial suits of the Han dynasty, intricately assembled from thousands of pieces of jade to ensure immortality. Jade was also seen as the essence of the cosmos—a fusion of the vital energies of heaven and earth. The Chinese language is rich in jade-related expressions that convey admiration and virtue! Therefore, jade items are timeless symbols of love, symbolizing lasting and sincere affection. Today, jade remains a precious heirloom, a solid investment, and a powerful emblem of cultural identity — connecting contemporary Chinese to our heritage. In this way, jade contains old and new life! Jade is not just a precious stone full of vitality. It is a cultural landmark — a bridge between old China and new China. Joy: What do you want to do with your collection? James: Right now, I'm planning to organize a traveling exhibition in Beijing, Shanghai and maybe Macau. As I said before, jade is full of vitality. Jade is a bridge between ancient China and modern China. So I don't want to limit my collection to the usual antique circles. I'm thinking about doing cross exhibitions with fashion, art and sport. I want jade to have a lively dialogue with contemporary, young and modern Chinese audiences!

item.title: Fire in Hong Kong | Considered future of bamboo scaffolding
item.description:
The fire in Tai Po sparked a debate around bamboo scaffolding, a tradition that was already at risk of extinction due to the lack of new specialized workers. Architect Nuno Soares believes that, before questioning the safety of bamboo, it is necessary to reinforce monitoring of the illegal use of flammable materials
Could an industry already at risk of extinction disappear more quickly than previously thought, due to the tragic fire in Hong Kong? The issue has been raised since, last week, a major fire in a residential complex under construction, in the Tai Po area, resulted in at least 159 deaths, according to the most recent report. The skyscrapers had bamboo scaffolding and other flammable materials used in the construction process. On Friday, Hong Kong authorities concluded that the fire was worsened by flammable bamboo scaffolding and foam insulation panels. Furthermore, Hong Kong fire chief Andy Yeung corroborated what many testimonies interviewed by AFP stated. “We found that the alarm systems in the eight buildings were not working properly,” he said. According to the Lusa agency, the report, still a preliminary expert, concluded that the materials used in works contributed to higher temperatures. “Based on the initial information we have, we believe that the fire started in the protective screen (plastic material to protect against the spread of dust and falling objects) located on the outside of the lower floors (…), and quickly escalated due to the panels” that protected the windows, said the security chief of the neighboring special administrative region, Chris Tang. To HM, the architect Nuno Soares, linked to the study of bamboo construction, and who has fought for its preservation, considers that before pointing blame at the material, it is necessary to reinforce the supervision of the shipyards. "We know that bamboo is difficult to ignite. In other words, bamboo burns, but it is difficult to burn and, when it does, the combustion is slow, and it is easy to fight [a possible fire]. Now when there is a net around it, which is not fireproof, everything catches fire very quickly, right? There is already known data [on the incident], and we know that the scaffolding was, in fact, made of bamboo, but there was a plastic net around it which was not fireproof, in addition to the use of Styrofoam to cover the windows, which is a highly flammable material”, he highlighted. Nuno Soares also referred to the occurrence, in Tai Po, of “problems with the fire detection and fighting system in the building itself, built in the 1980s, and which was already out of date”. “Several problems in inspection are also known, and with the data we have we are unable to conclude, in summary, that bamboo was the guiding principle in this situation, and we have to be rigorous in this type of analysis”, he added. Therefore, Nuno Soares considers that caution is needed and not to enter into simplistic or hasty analyses. “We cannot, with the data we have at the moment, say that bamboo has no responsibility whatsoever.” "If there had been that nylon net around the metal scaffolding, a very similar situation would have happened, because the fire would have spread through that net and then through the Styrofoam on the windows. Fire safety regulations are already quite strict in Macau and Hong Kong, but where I think there is room for improvement is in inspection," he said. A material question The Global Times newspaper wrote on Monday about the difficulties in putting an end to the construction of bamboo scaffolding in a short period of time. In an article entitled “Tradition under fire”, we read that “some defenders argue that bamboo scaffolding, as a traditional construction technique, is low-cost, flexible to assemble and disassemble, and especially suitable for the tight spaces of old urban neighborhoods”, with “contrary voices that focus on security risks”. Quoted by the same newspaper, Lee Kwong-sing, president of the Hong Kong Institute of Security Professionals, said that, given the available information, “the flammable materials on the external walls set fire to the safety nets, not the bamboo itself”. Demonstrating a similar position to Nuno Soares, the person in charge added that “even if metal scaffolding had been used, safety nets would have been necessary, and if flammable materials were not removed, the risk of fire would not change much”. Zhao Shixing, chief engineer of the Sichuan Provincial Institute of Architectural Design and Research, told the Global Times that bamboo's weaknesses lie in its safety and stability, as raw and untreated bamboo has a B2 combustibility rating according to China's standards, and can easily ignite when exposed to other flammable materials. Zhao said, therefore, that “this vulnerability was completely exposed in this fire.” According to the state newspaper, authorities in the neighboring city of Shenzhen had already banned the use of bamboo in 1994, and in January 2022 the country's Ministry of Housing and Urban-Rural Development banned the use of “bamboo (or wooden) scaffolding” in construction and municipal engineering works across the country. Difficult to erase tradition In special administrative regions, the construction of bamboo scaffolding continues to be a reality, despite the alleged lack of younger personnel interested in learning the technique. Nuno Soares highlights that the technique “is very deep-rooted”, having “existed for decades in Macau and Hong Kong”, surviving due to its versatility and being adaptable to local climate conditions. The architect also highlights among the decisive factors for the use of bamboo the “workmanship and type of high-rise constructions that are carried out in Macau and Hong Kong”. In the hours following the accident, Macau authorities carried out a series of inspections of construction sites, in addition to organizing dozens of lectures to raise awareness of the risks of fires. Such a stance was “wise and preventive”. "The bamboo scaffolding was not removed, but the flammable nets that were in several buildings in Macau were removed. What we need to do is more testing, that is, it is not enough to have the manufacturer's certificate saying that the material is fireproof. Inspection must be more rigorous." “One of the reasons why I think bamboo scaffolding has been so successful throughout the recent history of Macau and Hong Kong is because it is safe, in the sense that it resists winds and typhoons well, and protects workers who wear protective elements”, highlighted the architect. In general, Nuno Soares says that “it doesn’t make sense” to have a sudden, total ban on the use of bamboo in the construction of scaffolding. “Taking into account the data we have, this measure of preventing bamboo construction makes no sense.” When the fire was still far from being extinguished, the police had already announced the arrest of three suspects for “gross negligence” after the discovery of flammable materials abandoned during work, which allowed the fire to “spread quickly” due to the strong wind. Investigations continue. Quoted by CNN, Xinyan Huang, associate professor at the University of Hong Kong, declared that bamboo is “definitely a flammable material”. "This season is very dry in Hong Kong, so the possibility of the bamboo burning is very high. Once the combustion takes place, the fire spreads very quickly", he concluded. In a joint note from the Fire Department, Directorate of Land and Urban Construction Services, Directorate of Labor Affairs Services and Institute for Municipal Affairs, on Friday, the Macao SAR Executive said it was “extremely attentive to the serious fire that recently occurred in the neighboring region”, but did not reveal whether or not it will ban the use of bamboo. “After checking fire-fighting equipment, hazardous substance storage management and emergency evacuation routes, they all comply with applicable safety requirements.” Furthermore, and mentioning more recent statistical data, it is stated that “there are currently around 566 construction sites in Macau, of which more than 60 involve works with scaffolding”, with the promise of carrying out “intensive inspections of all works with scaffolding, requiring contractors to strictly comply with their fire prevention responsibilities”. However, the Executive admitted yesterday that it could replace bamboo scaffolding with metal ones, but only if there is “social consensus” between the population and construction companies, said Mak Tat Io, deputy director of Land and Urban Construction Services.

item.title: OECD | World economy expected to slow to 2.9% in 2026
item.description: The OECD predicts that global economic growth will slow down in 2026, falling from 3.2 percent this year to 2.9 percent next year, with economic activity facing “fragile prospects”, associated with the impact of tariffs on global trade. In the Economic Perspectives report, released yesterday, the Organization for Economic Cooperation and Development (OECD) points to a moderation in the trajectory of Gross Domestic Product (GDP) globally, with growth slowing from 3.3 percent recorded in 2024 to 3.2 percent in 2025 and to 2.9 percent in 2026, followed by a “small recovery” to 3.1 percent in 2027. “Growth is expected to slow down during the second half of this year [2025], as the anticipation of activity unfolds and higher effective customs duties on imports to the United States and China are reflected in company costs and final product prices, harming investment and trade growth”, describes the organization. “The projections are based on the technical assumption that the bilateral tariffs announced in mid-November will be maintained for the rest of the projection period, despite ongoing legal challenges in the United States”, he highlights. In the introduction to the report, OECD Secretary-General Mathias Cormann highlights that “the global economy has proven resilient this year, despite concerns about a more pronounced slowdown following the increase in trade barriers and significant political uncertainty”. However, it warns that the increase in customs duties should “gradually lead to higher prices, reducing the growth of household consumption and business investment”. “These prospects remain fragile”, warns the organization’s top official, stressing that if there is an increase in tariffs, this movement is expected to cause “significant damage to supply chains and global production” and there is a risk that high asset valuations, made “based on optimistic expectations of corporate profits” driven by Artificial Intelligence (AI), will lead to “potentially abrupt price corrections”. Asia on the rise In the document, the OECD notes that “high geopolitical and political uncertainty will also continue to weigh on domestic demand in many economies”, with emerging Asian economies expected to continue to be “responsible for the majority of global growth”. For the United States of America, the OECD predicts GDP growth to be “2.0 percent in 2025, 1.7 percent in 2026 and 1.9 percent in 2027”. China is expected to grow 5.0 percent in 2025, 4.4 percent in 2026 and 4.3 percent in 2027. In the second world economy, says the organization, “the end of the anticipation of exports, the imposition of higher customs duties on exports to the United States, the continued adjustment in the real estate sector and the weakening of budgetary support are expected to reduce growth”. Eurozone growth “is expected to slow slightly, from 1.3 percent in 2025 to 1.2 percent in 2026, before increasing to 1.4 percent in 2027, with increased trade frictions being offset by improved financial conditions, continued capital spending from Recovery and Resilience Mechanism funds, and the resilience of labor markets,” says the OECD.

item.title: Five Year Plan | Economist highlights focus on solving internal problems
item.description: Economist Maria Fernanda Ilhéu understands that the Central Government's 15th Five-Year Plan aims to consolidate regional economic aspects and resolve “aspects of the Chinese economy that are still problematic”, such as “weak domestic demand”. The position was taken at a seminar promoted by the Chinese Embassy in Lisbon What are the objectives proposed in China's 15th Five-Year Plan, whose public consultation ended on November 14th? For economist Maria Fernanda Ilhéu, former Macau resident and president of the Friends of the New Silk Road Association (ANRS), the plan could respond to “some aspects of the Chinese economy that are still problematic, such as weak domestic demand”. The position was taken at a seminar, held recently in Lisbon and promoted by the Chinese Embassy in Portugal, entitled “Interpretation of the 15th Five-Year Plan for National Economic and Social Development of China. Perspectives for Future China-Portugal Cooperation”. Maria Fernanda Ilhéu's speech, consulted by HM, was published by her on social media. For Maria Fernanda Ilhéu, “despite government stimuli, domestic consumption remains low in its contribution to GDP [Gross Domestic Product]”, and “some bottlenecks and obstacles are impeding economic flows, such as the delay in agricultural and rural modernization and the pressure on employment”. At this point, the economist highlighted the “graduates who do not find jobs that match their qualifications”, in addition to the fact that the country still hopes to achieve “per capita income growth, which is intended to be more accelerated and balanced in regions that are still very poor”. In turn, there are still “some difficulties in public services and social support”, while “the aging of the population presents challenges to economic development and the provision of services for the well-being of the population over 65 years of age”. Maria Fernanda Ilhéu cited data on this aspect, relating to 2024, when the elderly represented 14.1 percent of the population, 4.7 percent more compared to 2014. Based on the document presented by Beijing, the economist said that the 15th Five-Year Plan also intends to “project the Chinese economy towards self-sustainability and global competition”, and, in her view, the country faces “three challenges”. They are the “great volubility” which is described by Chinese authorities as “strategic opportunities that exist alongside risks and challenges, while uncertainties and unpredictable factors are growing”. A changing model Maria Fernanda Ilhéu also highlights that “China's growth model is changing, with population changes, corrections in the real estate sector and decreasing returns on investment in infrastructure, requiring new factors to maintain the pace of growth”. Furthermore, “technology has become fundamental on the stage of global competition”, something that “requires and pressures China towards self-reliant innovation and industrial resilience”. The economist does not forget the regional issues, which Macau is included in, particularly regarding the “objective for some cities and super regions” and the “dynamizing role of the Yangtze River Delta and the Guangdong-Hong Kong – Macau Greater Bay Area”. In this context, the aim is to “achieve progress in industrialization, computerization, urbanization and agricultural modernization through new forms of production, and fostering new patterns of development”. The idea is that there will be a “modernization of the industry”, in which the “frontline sectors” will be “artificial intelligence (AI), advanced robotics, quantum computing, semiconductors, biotechnologies and new generation of information and aerospace technology”. For Maria Fernanda Ilhéu, these areas are “foundational in a strategy of international competitiveness, resilience and growth multiplier effects”. The importance of Lusophony The economist also defended that the lines drawn up in the 15th Five-Year Plan point to the promotion of the Yangtze River Delta, including the province of Zhejiang, “homeland of the majority of overseas Chinese who chose Portugal to live and work”, or even, in the Greater Bay Area, which includes Macau, “one of the central vertices, where the centuries-old Portuguese presence is a strategic asset in cooperation between Portugal and China”. For her, the “priority areas of cooperation” should focus on green energy, namely battery production, green hydrogen and mobility, “sectors where China leads”. Digitalization and AI, particularly in the construction of “digital health” and “smart cities” tools, in terms of logistics and ports. Other strategic points are infrastructure, health, biotechnology and cooperation in scientific research and industrial production in AI, he pointed out. Bet on consumption According to an analysis by the China Briefing portal, linked to the consultancy Dezan Shira & Associates, China is currently in “very different conditions” compared to the last Five-Year Plan. Today the worst phase and consequent impacts of Covid-19 appear to have passed, however, there is “pressure on domestic industries” that will continue “to shape economic policy in the coming years”. Furthermore, the fact that Donald Trump is once again in the White House is highlighted, referring to the United States as “the largest individual trading partner and main economic rival”. In this way, the Five-Year Plan designed for the years 2026 to 2030 “will be drawn up with these issues in mind”, and “priorities will probably focus on improving economic resilience, including the diversification of trading partners and reducing dependence on imports” of products and materials considered “critical”. It is also intended to “stimulate domestic consumption and improve internal capabilities in key technologies”. The same analysis reflects a speech given by President Xi Jinping, in April this year, in which he points out that the 15th Five-Year Plan must “practically evaluate how changes in the international scenario affect China”, and an adjustment must be made, “optimizing the country's economic structure”. Regarding the promotion of domestic consumption, highlight is the announcement, on November 26th, of an action plan presented by the Ministry of Industry and Information Technology of China, which aims, according to the state agency Xinhua, “the formation of multimillion-dollar consumer sectors in the coming years”. The use of artificial intelligence (AI) seems to be the norm, such as smart refrigerators “that can recommend a shopping list and glasses that can respond to various user commands”. Xinhua writes about the aforementioned plan that “China intends to form three massive consumption sectors, namely elderly care products, smart connected vehicles and consumer electronics, with a market scale that will reach trillions of yuan by 2027”. In addition, “ten categories of high-demand consumer goods worth 100 billion yuan (about 14 billion US dollars) will be promoted, including products for children and babies, smart wearable devices, cosmetics, fitness equipment, and food and pet products.” Double news The fourth plenary session of the 20th Central Committee of the Chinese Communist Party, held in October, adopted recommendations for the Five-Year Plan, which focused on maintaining the “domestic demand expansion strategy” with efforts “to ensure that new demand drives new supply”, also promoting “positive interactions between consumption and investment and between supply and demand”. Not even on purpose, the China Briefing portal adds that the 15th Five-Year Plan “should dedicate significant space to the development of the ‘AI Plus’ initiative and supporting sectors, with policies aimed at promoting investment, fiscal support, talent training and public-private collaborations”. The 15th Five-Year Plan should also “define carbon emission targets and realign the decarbonization strategy”, and the country “is changing the main decarbonization strategy”, moving “from the focus on reducing total energy consumption to concentrating on reducing total carbon emissions”. It is worth highlighting the fact that the final version of the 15th Five-Year Plan will only be presented during the so-called Two Sessions of March next year, of the National People's Congress and the Chinese People's Political Consultative Conference, when it will be adopted and implemented by the authorities in Beijing.

item.title: Evolution | African genomes point to the origins of the human species
item.description: Homo sapiens has existed for at least 300,000 years, but its exact origin remains unknown and a new study has ruled out the hypothesis that it evolved in East Africa and expanded south. The study, based on the analysis of ancient genomes of people who lived from the Stone Age – 10,200 years ago – to 150 years ago in southern Africa, argues that a group of individuals lived in partial isolation for several hundred thousand years. By analyzing their genomes, researchers found genetic adaptations that likely shaped H. sapiens as a species. Details of the study – the most comprehensive to date on ancient African DNA – conducted by researchers from Uppsala University (Sweden) and the University of Johannesburg, were published on Wednesday in the magazine “Nature”, reported the agency Efe. “We have long known that Southern Africa was inhabited (…). We can now demonstrate that Homo sapiens existed and evolved in Southern Africa over a long period and that this region played a significant role in human evolution, perhaps the most important of all”, highlighted Mattias Jakobsson, geneticist at Uppsala University and main author of the study. The team analyzed the ancient genomes of 28 individuals from southern Africa and compared them with those of their contemporaries from other parts of the world. They discovered that the Stone Age inhabitants of southern Africa lived in isolation for a long period. “This group appears to have remained genetically isolated for at least 200,000 years, and it was only around 1,400 years ago that clear traces of genetic flow within this group began to emerge, when DNA from individuals from East and West Africa began to appear in individuals from Southern Africa,” explained Jakobsson. Although no new groups migrated to southern Africa until about 1,400 years ago, genetic data suggests that members of the southern population migrated north during certain climatic periods. In fact, genetic material — dating back to around 8,000 years ago — from this southern population has been found in individuals from present-day Malawi, making it possible that southern migrations also occurred earlier. Techniques and variations A large part of the human remains analyzed were found in the Matjes River Rock Shelter (South Africa), an archaeological site with remains dating back approximately 10,000 to 1,500 years. This site also revealed different tools from each historical period, made with different techniques. However, the individuals are genetically practically identical throughout the entire period, that is, there is no evidence of immigration or population exchange, “exactly the opposite of what happened in Europe, where cultural changes tend to coincide with population migrations”, analyzed Jakobsson. In the study, researchers identified 79 DNA variants unique to Homo sapiens, distinct from those found in Neanderthals, Denisovans, chimpanzees and gorillas. Seven of these variants, related to kidney function, were “clearly overrepresented”. The authors believe that these variants are linked to the unique human ability to cool the body through sweat, which requires a good ability to regulate the body's water balance. They also found variants involved in the immune system and neuronal growth. More than 40 percent of these variants are associated with neurons and brain growth, suggesting a role in cognitive evolution. Additionally, several genes have been linked to attention, a mental ability that may have evolved differently in Homo sapiens compared to Neanderthals and Denisovans.

item.title: What is known about the fire that killed 151 people in Hong Kong
item.description: Hong Kong continued today to count the victims of the fire that devastated a residential complex on Wednesday, the most serious in decades, with at least 151 dead. Authorities in the neighboring Chinese special administrative region of Macau detained 11 people on suspicion of negligence, but the cause of the fire has not yet been determined. Here is what is known about the tragedy, according to the France-Presse (AFP) news agency: What happened? The fire alarm was raised at 2:50 pm on Wednesday. The fire hit a real estate complex with 1,984 homes and eight towers of 31 floors each, called Wang Fuk Court, located in Tai Po, in the New Territories, in the north of Hong Kong. The complex, opened in 1983, was undergoing renovation work, but continued to be occupied by around four thousand people who lived there. Immense flames spread extremely quickly between the buildings, which were surrounded by bamboo scaffolding and protective nets. Hundreds of firefighters were mobilized to provide assistance and extinguish the fire. Firefighters only declared the end of operations against the fire this morning (Friday). How many victims? The most recent provisional balance this afternoon was 128 dead [151 is the most recent number], of which 89 had not yet been identified, according to Hong Kong's security chief, Chris Tang. More than a hundred people were still missing at the same time. There were also 79 injured, 11 of which were in critical condition. Family members toured hospitals and morgues looking for victims. It is the deadliest building fire worldwide since 1980, excluding fires in nightclubs, prisons or shopping centers, according to research in the disaster database at the University of Leuven (Belgium). It is also the most serious in Hong Kong since 1948. It is still unknown to what extent the balance could increase due to the number of people about whom there is still no news. Among the missing people, there are 19 Filipino and 11 Indonesian domestic workers, according to data from the Mission for Migrant Workers organization cited by the local newspaper South China Morning Post (SCMP). Firefighters finished their inspection of all homes today, Friday. What caused the tragedy? The initial causes of the fire have not been rigorously established. The security chief admitted that the investigation could take three or four weeks. Based on preliminary findings, Tang said that the fire started in the lower parts of the shipyard's nets that protected against dust and falling objects. The spread of the flames, according to Tang, was favored by the use of bamboo for scaffolding, common in Hong Kong, and flammable materials such as foam panels that protected the windows. Hong Kong fire chief Andy Yeung also corroborated what many witnesses interviewed by AFP said. “We found that the alarm systems in the eight buildings were not working properly,” he said. Who is responsible? The anti-corruption commission announced today the arrest of seven men and one woman, aged between 40 and 63. These are two people responsible for the project office that prepared the renovation, two construction managers, three scaffolding subcontractors and an intermediary. The police had already announced the arrest of three suspects for “gross negligence” after the discovery of flammable materials abandoned during work, which allowed the fire to “spread quickly” due to the strong wind. The exact level of involvement of the suspects in starting the fire is unclear. Authorities ordered the inspection of all public housing complexes undergoing major renovations, according to the SCMP newspaper. What is the fire risk in Hong Kong? Hong Kong, a special administrative region of China with 7.5 million inhabitants, is one of the most densely populated places in the world, which increases the risk of urban disasters. The average population density is more than 7,100 inhabitants per square kilometer, with vast steep and unbuildable areas. In urbanized areas, population density is up to three times higher, a world record. This financial center, where space is limited and real estate prices are among the highest in the world, is famous for the skyscrapers surrounding the bay. The last few decades have been marked by the construction of a profusion of residential towers that can have more than 50 floors. Most of the new construction projects have taken place in the mainland of the green New Territories region, where the Tai Po neighborhood is located. Hong Kong has 569 buildings over 150 meters tall, the highest number in the world, according to data from the specialized international NGO CTBUH (Council on Tall Buildings and Urban Habitat).

item.title: Hong Kong | Deadliest fire since 1918 leads to investigation
item.description: There have been 128 deaths and 200 people missing in what was the biggest fire in the history of Hong Kong, in the New Territories. Authorities have, however, moved towards an anti-corruption investigation given the scale of the incident in Tai Po. The Lusa agency reports the despair of many families The tragedy is far from abating in Hong Kong. The fire that occurred this Wednesday in the Tai Po area, in the New Territories, in a complex of buildings under construction, is already considered one of the largest in the history of the territory and the victims are still being counted – at the time of writing this edition there were 55 dead and 250 people missing. Today, Friday, the numbers rose to 128 dead and 200 missing. Yesterday, at the end of the day, the fire was gradually coming under control, with another 55 survivors being rescued. According to a report from the Lusa agency, the families of those missing remained in a feeling of despair yesterday, given the lack of answers. “Did you see this girl?” a mother asks the Lusa journalist in Cantonese, before switching to English. “Did you see my daughter or the ‘helper’?” he says, using the expression used in Hong Kong for domestic workers. The woman, surnamed Cheng, waves a piece of paper on which she has printed a photograph of her five-year-old daughter, Hannah Cheng, and a copy of the work permit of her maid, Indonesian Maryan. The family lived in Wang Tai House, part of the Wang Fuk Court residential complex that burned down. A spokeswoman for the Indonesian consulate in Hong Kong confirmed to the South China Morning Post that the dead included two Indonesian maids. "I haven't seen them since the fire started. Please, have you seen them?", Cheng begs everyone he meets at the entrance to Alice Ho Miu Ling Nethersole, the hospital located closest to the social housing complex, in Tai Po. The fire department said it had already managed to contact several of the 279 people who were initially listed as missing. The temperature “is very high and there are floors where we cannot contact the people who called for help, but we will continue to try”, assured the deputy director of the fire department, Derek Armstrong Chan. A post was circulating on social media from another mother, desperate for not being able to contact her in-laws, who were taking care of her six-month-old daughter, in Wang Fuk Court. "Almost 24 hours have passed [since the last contact] (…) My daughter needs to be breastfed otherwise she will die. Can anyone tell me if she was saved or not?", wrote Winnie Hui. This is already the deadliest fire since 1918, when Hong Kong was still a British colony. That year, a fire caused the collapse of the main grandstand at the Happy Valley racecourse, causing more than 600 deaths. More than 700 firefighters are involved in fighting the flames, in addition to rescue teams and police. Population helps As the hours passed, support from the population began to arrive, both in terms of physical and financial presence, at various shelters for the homeless. Serena, 16, was carrying a box of bottled water to deliver to a secondary school in Tai Po, converted into one of the temporary shelters for those affected by the fire. In addition to the 900 residents of the Wang Fuk Court residential complex, authorities ordered residents of the nearby Kwong Fuk Estate to evacuate their homes as a precaution. “This is my school, but we don't have classes today because of the fire”, explains the young woman to Lusa, who joined several colleagues to buy and donate supplies, including cookies and instant pasta. The school is just over two kilometers from the residential complex that burned down. On the second day, columns of smoke continued to rise into the sky, with the smell of burning in the air. “Everyone knows someone who lived in Wang Fuk”, highlights Serena. “We never thought this could happen here”, he adds. But it is not only in Tai Po, located closer to the border with the metropolis of Shenzhen than to the center of Hong Kong, that the population has mobilized to help. An elderly woman came from Tuen Mun, 30 kilometers away, with blankets and clothes. “It’s not enough for someone who lost everything they had”, laments the resident, surnamed Fong. The social neighborhood, built in the 1980s, is made up of eight towers with nearly 30 floors and a total of 1,984 apartments, where around four thousand people lived. According to the local press, the fire also led many people to try to donate blood, running out of appointments in the center of Causeway Bay yesterday. Meanwhile, the Hong Kong Government created a fund this Thursday with 300 million Hong Kong dollars for the victims. At a press conference, postponed twice, the Chief Executive, John Lee Ka-chiu, said that the fund, created at the state-owned Bank of China, began accepting donations from 7pm. John Lee also announced that the Government would distribute, throughout the day, 10 thousand Hong Kong dollars to each family affected by the fire in the Wang Fuk Court social housing complex. Ongoing investigations The scale of the tragedy has already led Hong Kong authorities to move forward with an anti-corruption investigation. Hong Kong's Independent Anti-Corruption Commission has set up “a working group to launch a full investigation into possible corruption in the major Wang Fuk Court renovation project in Tai Po.” In a statement, the commission justified the decision with “the immense public interest involved”. There are now three working groups: one to investigate the fire, another to deal with emergency donation resources and one for the relocation of affected families. Meanwhile, police arrested three men on suspicion of involuntary manslaughter after discovering flammable materials left during maintenance work that led to the fire spreading quickly through the bamboo floors. John Lee, Chief Executive of the HKSAR, said the Department of Home Affairs and Youth has reserved 1,000 apartments in youth hostels and hotels for affected residents to stay for a maximum period of two weeks. They will then be moved to 1,800 subsidized apartments reserved for them to settle in temporarily, he added. The official also indicated that the Government is preparing a list of goods that Hong Kong will request from China's central government, including unmanned aircraft ('drones') for inspections and materials for laboratory tests. Meanwhile, inspections are also being carried out at all real estate complexes that are undergoing major works. “The Government ordered the inspection of all real estate complexes in the city that are undergoing major renovations, to check the safety of scaffolding and construction materials,” said John Lee Ka-chiu in a message published on the social network Facebook. The complex of eight 31-storey buildings was undergoing facade renovations. Campaign suspended The leader of the Hong Kong Government admitted yesterday that the elections for the Legislative Council of Hong Kong, scheduled for December 7, could be postponed. “We will carry out a thorough analysis and make a decision within a few days, based on the overall interests of Hong Kong,” said John Lee Ka-chiu, after an emergency meeting with heads of various government departments. The Chief Executive added that the debates between candidates for the Legislative Council of Hong Kong that were scheduled for Thursday and today have been postponed, with no new date set.
