The remaining election campaign activities were also suspended, John Lee told journalists. "The Government is committed to dealing with this major disaster. Our priority now is to fight the fire", highlighted the leader. "The top priority is to extinguish the fire and rescue the trapped residents. The second task is to treat the injured, the third is to deal with the consequences, and then we will carry out a thorough investigation," Lee added. "As for other matters, we will decide what to do in a few days, after we coordinate our work," said the government leader. Leaders react Xi Jinping, Chinese President, yesterday expressed condolences for the victims of the fire, calling for “intense rescue efforts to minimize losses”, reported the Xinhua agency. The President also declared that he gave great importance to the accident, having immediately requested permanent updates on the work of the rescue team. Xi Jinping instructed the director of the Central Government Liaison Office in Hong Kong to convey condolences. Another political leader who also spoke out about the tragedy was the Prime Minister of Timor-Leste, Xanana Gusmão. He referred to the death of the 128 people as “tragic” and “deeply painful”. “Our hearts are with the families and friends of all those who lost their lives, as well as with those who remain missing”, he highlighted, in a press release. Xanana Gusmão also paid tribute to the “extraordinary courage of firefighters, first responders and all those who work tirelessly in rescue and recovery operations”.

item.title: East Timor | April Revolution left “difficult memories”
item.description: Marisa Ramos Gonçalves, researcher at the University of Coimbra, addresses, in a study, the experiences of the Timorese during the period of the 25th of April Marisa Ramos Gonçalves, a researcher at the Center for Social Sciences at the University of Coimbra, considered that the April revolution in Timor-Leste left “difficult memories” and that reconciliation is fundamental for “national cohesion”. “When we talk about the 25th of April in Timor, we know that we are talking about difficult memories that have left marks to this day due to the internal conflict and the violation of human rights during the occupation”, Marisa Ramos Gonçalves, who is currently carrying out a study on that period in the country, told Lusa. Marisa Ramos Gonçalves is also a member of the International Advisory Board of the National Chega Center (in Timor-Leste), which, among other activities, documents the history of the conflict in Timor-Leste between 1974 and 1999. The researcher explained to Lusa that the objective is to understand the other side of the story “based on the experiences of the Timorese of the 25th of April and this period of transition, which gives rise to a proclamation of independence, but which is very short compared to the occupation”. “This collective memory of the Timorese is inseparable, both from the internal conflict and from the human tragedy that is the Indonesian invasion and occupation”, highlighted Marisa Ramos Gonçalves. The unilateral proclamation of Timor-Leste's independence, on November 28, 1975, came after a period marked by clashes between the East Timorese and already under the shadow of the possibility of occupation of the territory by Indonesia, which came to fruition on December 7, 1975. Asked about reconciliation between East Timorese, the researcher said that the “issue has been on the table”. "It is necessary to achieve reconciliation between Timorese who were on opposite sides during the civil conflict with different options for the future of Timor. At the time, UDT wanted an association with Portugal for a few more years before independence, Fretilin wanted immediate independence, and Apodeti, which wanted integration into Indonesia and they are all Timorese", he stated. According to Marisa Gonçalves, the National Chega Center wants “this to start being on the table, because it has not been easy until now for Timorese who suffered torture or were persecuted during the period of internal conflict to speak openly”. "But we are already beginning to see this possibility when talking about violence and torture, which existed for a very short period in 1975, but which left strong marks. There is also a reconciliation at the level of political leadership that is yet to be achieved and I think this is also complicated. It is a reconciliation of the entire society", stated Marisa Ramos Gonçalves. Larger opening Considering reconciliation between Timorese people as fundamental for social cohesion, the researcher highlights, on the other hand, that the new generations formed in the Indonesian period and the younger ones “are completely prepared for this reconciliation”. “They are not so tied to previous conflicts and they really want to reconcile and, therefore, I think they are already looking at that future, they already think that all people are part of the Timorese Nation, including the Timorese who are in West Timor”, where there is a community of around 80,000 people, he highlighted. "It is also important that the older generation reconciles, especially because it is still a generation, the so-called generation of 75, that continues in power. It would also be interesting for them to take the initiative to get closer", he added. Regarding the study she is carrying out, Marisa Ramos Gonçalves said that there is a lack of historical research in Timor-Leste and that it is good to understand the expectations that people had not only in relation to the 25th of April, but also in relation to the political transition. “It means knowing the narratives, the experiences, the memories of Timorese people of various geographic origins, professional occupations and party affiliations about the same historical moment”, he explained, highlighting that reconciliation is also achieved through the writing of history.

item.title: Taxis | Request more services per application
item.description: The Association of Automobile Traders and Workers of Macau considers that Macau should have mobile phone applications to hail taxis similar to Didi or Uber, calling on the Government to bring this service to the territory when launching the public consultation to review the regulations on passenger transport in Taxis. Speaking to the newspaper Ou Mun, the president of the association, Leng Sai Vai, praised the importance of this type of service, stressing that currently taxi drivers can only have customers in nearby areas, such as casinos or border posts, with customers in areas further away from stopping points having difficulty calling a vehicle. The person in charge believes that creating these applications in Macau can bring more customers, increasing the effectiveness of the service and providing greater convenience to passengers.

item.title: APAVT | Macau is international “Preferred Destination” in 2026
item.description: The Portuguese Association of Travel and Tourism Agencies once again chose Macau as the association's Preferred Destination in 2026, which will allow for reinforced cooperation. Helena de Senna Fernandes praised the continuation of the good work resulting from the partnership with the Portuguese association "Macau and the Portuguese Association of Travel and Tourism Agencies (APAVT) decided that they should not stop. That is why I convey to you with great joy that we have decided, Macau and APAVT, that Macau will be APAVT's preferred international destination throughout 2026", stated the president of APAVT, Pedro Costa Ferreira in the territory. The 50th APAVT National Congress, which has been taking place since Tuesday in Macau, ended yesterday, and was attended by more than a thousand professionals, a record number, to debate the future of the tourism sector. Macau hosted for the sixth time what is considered the largest congress in the Portuguese tourism sector. "I can't be happier. You know my status in my last term. I'm fulfilling a dream, which is to return to Macau and work with Macau again. (…) The Congress has been, in my opinion, memorable from the point of view of the themes, but it has also been memorable from the point of view of the number, it is the biggest ever, and it has been memorable from the point of view of reception capacity", reinforced Pedro Costa Ferreira. APAVT's Preferred Destination is a “very broad” program, which has two fundamental parts, communication and marketing, and which, in this way, helps the chosen destination to promote itself. “It means that in all our presences, we will have Macau with us and, therefore, we have this communication”, added the president of the association, remembering that in this way a relationship that has existed for many years is reinforced. Old friends “The return of Congress to our city this year and the designation of Macau, along with China, as a Preferred Destination for 2026, paves the way for us to continue working well”, said the director of Tourism Services, Helena de Senna Fernandes. The main new feature of Destino Preferido in 2026 will be the launch of an 'e-learning' program about Macau for travel agents from Germany, Finland and the Netherlands, just like the program that was launched in Portugal in 2024. The 'e-learning' will be developed by APAVT and Macau Tourism, in collaboration with the European Confederation of Associations of Travel Agencies and Tour Operators (European Confederation of Travel Agents’ and Tour Operators’ Associations [ECTAA]). Pedro Costa Ferreira also recalled that this congress has several “special meanings”, firstly “because it is the sixth” in Macau and because it was chosen “to conclude the celebration of the 75th anniversary” of the association. APAVT says it has accredited 1,039 congressmen from 172 different flights, congressmen who “will now visit several provinces in China in collaboration with Macau Tourism”.

item.title: Airport | Secretary speaks of “strategic asset”
item.description: Raymond Tam, Secretary for Transport and Public Works, said yesterday, in connection with the 30th anniversary of Macau International Airport (AIM), that this infrastructure has become “an engine of socio-economic development” for the territory, as well as “an essential gateway for Macau's integration into regional development and international cooperation”. Opened in 1995, AIM “has seen continuous development in its operations”, and has broken “successive records in passenger movement and cargo volume”, highlighted the secretary, who has not forgotten “the constant improvement in the quality of services and operational efficiency”. Raymond Tam considered AIM “a fundamental strategic asset to promote the diversified economic development of Macau and support its integration into the national development context”.

item.title: Patriotism | Outstanding importance of General Ye Ting's residence
item.description: Taking into account the reopening, yesterday, of General Ye Ting's former residence, at number 76 Rua do Almirante Costa Cabral, two academics highlighted, to the newspaper Ou Mun, the importance of this new museum space for patriotic education. Lam Fat Iam, director of the Faculty of Human and Social Sciences of the Macau Polytechnic University, and also a deputy, said that this residence represents a testimony to the general's life story, particularly the time he was in Macau. The official also highlighted that the pieces on display build a clear line of patriotic education, revealing the struggles that took place in China's modern history. Ieng Weng Fat, historian, stated that the Cultural Institute improved the general's presentation, allowing the public to learn about the contributions that Ye Ting made during the Second World War, in the fight against the Japanese invasion, to learn more about patriotic education and to foster, among young people, a love for Macau.

item.title: Work | Two-thirds rest only 1 or 1.5 days a week
item.description: A FAOM survey revealed that around 60 percent of workers did not receive a salary update this year and two thirds did not have a two-day weekly rest. Leong Sun Iok wants the Government to give clear guidance to companies to prioritize hiring residents and set a minimum quota for locals Frozen wages, work overload, financial insecurity and unfair competition with very low wages from non-residents were the main concerns revealed by around 2,000 workers who responded to a survey on working conditions in 2025. The work, presented yesterday, was carried out by the Macau Workers' Associations (FAOM). For 60 percent of those interviewed, there were no salary increases this year, while 10 percent even had salary cuts. Furthermore, close to two-thirds of workers complained of an excessive workload, with their weekly rest period reduced to one day or one and a half days. Another situation that disrupts the balance between life and work is technological access that allows work tasks to be transferred to free time and home. This situation once again became the target of complaints from workers, leading FAOM officials to ask the Government to clearly define the parameters of the “right to be offline”. To achieve this, workers must be entitled to overtime compensation, or shift work wages. In addition to these problems, there were frequent reports of a lack of stability and financial “cushion”, causing feelings of insecurity regarding the future. The bogeyman Echoing one of FAOM's political slogans, interviewees consider that labor policies do not effectively prioritize local people in access to employment. As such, 63 percent of respondents revealed a lack of clarity in the protection measures for resident workers. At this point, deputy Leong Sun Iok, stated that “although current laws already define the priority of local residents, the Government has never outlined clear requirements for companies in relation to human resources hiring practices”. The result is a lack of effectiveness in achieving the priority. One solution, pointed out by the deputy, would be the firm application of quotas or minimum proportion of residents in the human resources of each company, as happens with management positions in gaming concessionaires. Leong Sun Iok believes that in this way, employers would be “incentivized” to train local employees. The excessively low wages of non-resident workers, and the resulting unfair competition caused by the salary gap, was highlighted by 60 percent of respondents. Leong Sun Iok argues that the Government should refuse requests to hire non-residents when the salaries proposed by employers are too low.

item.title: GP Macau | Che Sai Wang wants faster disassembly
item.description: The deputy is concerned about the road removal works and points out that the delay disrupts the number of parking spaces, the transport of children to schools and makes life difficult for residents. Che Sai Wang defended the need for the Government to speed up work on dismantling the Macau Grand Prix facilities. The position of the deputy linked to the Macau Public Service Workers Association (ATFPM) was taken in a written questioning. According to the interview, Che is a supporter of the Grand Prix, which he stated is “a milestone in Macau's identity, with positive impacts on tourism, the economy and international visibility”. “It continues to be a vital component of the Government’s strategy to establish Macau as an ‘Event City’”, he highlighted. However, unlike what happens with the assemblies, Che expects the work to remove the track and additional facilities to be faster. “Although the Government demonstrates high efficiency in pre-race construction, the removal of barriers and restoration of roads and community functions after the event often proceed at a different pace – slow, time-consuming and without clear communication”, he reported. The deputy also indicates that this position is based on the population's complaints: “Numerous residents report that, days after the end of the event, sections of the roads remain partially blocked by barriers and temporary installations are not removed, with areas around the reservoir and close to the Greater Lisbon curve being the most affected”, he said. "Roads are not fully back to normal and designated parking spaces remain unavailable, seriously disrupting daily commutes, school transport, child pick-up and commercial deliveries. This exacerbates traffic congestion and diversions," he added. More information Having presented the problem, the deputy wants to know if the Government will start to better disseminate information with the calendar of dismantling work in different areas of the territory. “Will the services consider publishing a clear and publicly accessible ‘Post-Event Restoration Progress Bulletin’ in the future?” “This bulletin must detail the calendar of dismantling works by road section, being updated daily, clearly showing the progress of dismantling, reopening times, parking arrangements and explanations for any delays caused by road closures”, he indicated. The deputy also questioned the Executive about the definition of strict deadlines for dismantling work, to combat the “phenomenon of ‘fast construction, but slow dismantling’”. Finally, Che Sai Wang questions whether the definition of strict deadlines for dismantling can be applied in contracts awarding the assembly of the runway to complementary facilities, to resolve the problem.

item.title: IAM | Chao Wai Ieng with renewed mandate
item.description: The mandate of the president of the Institute for Municipal Affairs (IAM), Chao Wai Ieng, was renewed until May 31, according to an order from the Chief Executive published yesterday in the Official Bulletin. The renewal comes after Chao Wai Ieng has served around a year in his role, which he assumed in December last year, replacing José Tavares. The order considers that Chao has “appropriate experience and professional capacity to carry out his duties”, as is normally the case in this type of document. Chao Wai Ieng has been director of Identification Services since May 2022, and has a degree in engineering from the National Taiwan University and in Law from the University of Macau. He joined the Public Service in 2003 and worked at the Commissioner Against Corruption between February 2004 and December 2019, when he was chosen as an advisor to the Secretary for Administration and Justice's office. Mak Kim Meng's term as vice-president of the IAM was also renewed. Mak joined IAM in 1999 and over the years he held different positions. From 2010 until last year, he was one of the members of the IAM Board of Directors. With regard to the Board of Directors, the Chief Executive also renewed until May 31st the mandates of Isabel Celeste Jorge, Ung Sau Hong, To Sok I and Tam Wai Fong. DSEDT | Yau Yin Wah's mandate renewed Yau Yun Wah's mandate as director of the Economic and Technological Development Services (DSEDT) was renewed for a period of one year, according to an order published yesterday in the Official Bulletin. Before becoming director of economic services, where he replaced the current secretary for Economy and Finance, Tai Kin Ip, Yau Yun Wah was deputy director of Commercial Affairs Services of the Guangdong-Macao Deep Cooperation Zone in Hengqin. He has a degree in Commerce from Chengchi University in Taiwan and a master's degree in Public Administration from the National Institute of Administration of China. Macau Foundation | Lei Wai Nong reappointed The former Secretary for Economy and Finance, Lei Wai Nong, will continue to serve as a member of the Board of Directors of the Macau Foundation. The information was released yesterday, through an order published in the Official Bulletin. The former governor will maintain the previous privileges of secretary, as defined by the first appointment order, published in December 2024. “The member of the Board of Directors […] benefits from the benefits provided for in the legal regime of the public service for the management position”, it was indicated. Lei Wai Nong will also maintain his previous salary, in the order of 85 thousand patacas per month, to which are added typical public service benefits.

item.title: COP30 – Success or failure?
item.description:
The 30th United Nations Conference on Climate Change, promoted by the United Nations Environment Program (UNEP), took place for the first time in a Portuguese-speaking country, in the middle of the Amazon. It should be noted that Brazil, a country rich in oil, the eighth producer in the world, had the courage to host COP30. The first few days were not very encouraging, with several popular demonstrations taking place, some promoted by indigenous people from the Amazon. There was even a tense moment when a group of representatives of the Munduruku people, made up of indigenous people from the Amazon basin, blocked the entrance to the Conference facilities, forcing hundreds of delegates to remain outside for some time, in torrid heat. The main motivation for this demonstration can be attributed to the fact that these people were victims of illegal gold mining, the construction of hydroelectric plants and deforestation. Despite the measures taken by the current Brazilian government to prohibit the illegal exploration of minerals, several rivers in the Amazon basin continue to be polluted due to this exploitation. Although the era of land grabbers1 is already in decline, the indigenous people of the Amazon continue to be the target of illegal practices by those who try to occupy the lands allocated to them by law. There were other demonstrations with a significant number of participants, including a parade with more than two hundred boats with around 5,000 participants, in Guajará Bay, where the Acará, Guamá and Moju rivers converge. The protests, in addition to addressing climate change, also focused on various aspects related to the exploration of minerals, particularly with regard to projects promoted by Canada in South American countries. In addition to the demonstrations, the organization was faced with a fire in one of the Blue Zone pavilions, an area intended for official meetings between delegations and press conferences. Not since COP26 (Glasgow, 2021) have there been such expressive demonstrations against the mildness with which governments deal with the climate crisis. There is no doubt that the current government of Brazil is committed to the fight against deforestation and other illegal practices with strong repercussions on the emission of greenhouse gases (GHG), the main cause, according to the IPCC, of ​​climate change. Contrary to the previous government, headed by an avowed denialist, who refused to allow the 25th Conference of the Parties to take place in Brazil, breaking a previous commitment, the current president committed himself to hosting the 30th COP. There is, however, a certain ambiguity in the Brazilian political system: while the president pulls one way, the National Congress often pulls the other. This is what happened with the so-called “Devastation Bill”, also referred to as the General Environmental Licensing Law. While Lula da Silva was ideologically on the side of environmentalists, vetoing several aspects related to environmental protection of this bill, it returned to the National Congress, which annulled most of the vetoes, which allows offshore oil exploration to go ahead, relatively close to the mouth of the Amazon River, which could have strong environmental implications. +++ The Conference began on the 10th and ended on November 22nd, one day later than the scheduled date. The extension was due to the incompatibility between several participants' points of view on the final declaration. As in previous conferences, there were serious disagreements about the final text, given that, for some, it would be important to renew (and reinforce) what had already been previously agreed with regard to the abandonment of fossil fuels and, for others, it would be to camouflage this recommendation. Unfortunately, it was the latter who imposed their will, meaning that the recommendation expressed at COP 28 (Dubai, 2023) was not renewed, in which, for the first time, the need to abandon fossil fuels and accelerate the energy transition was officially recognized. The main opponents to this reference, in the final declaration, were Saudi Arabia, India and the Russian Federation. The European Union ended up giving in after ensuring that some of its red lines would be respected, namely inserting in the final text the mention of the need to not exceed the 1.5 ºC increase in global warming by the end of the 21st century (in relation to pre-industrial levels) and the objective of tripling the budget for adaptation to climate change in developing countries António Guterres, Secretary-General of the United Nations, addressing journalists during COP30, emphasized that no country can combat the climate crisis in isolation, and that the Conference demonstrated that multilateralism remains active. It cannot be said that the success of COP21 and COP28 was achieved, in the first of which (Paris, 2015) the Paris Agreement was adopted, a legally binding treaty that involved almost all countries in the world, which committed to making efforts to ensure that the increase in global warming did not exceed 2°C, preferably less than 1.5°C, and to proceed with the preparation of so-called Nationally Determined Contributions. NDCs2”), to be updated every five years. However, some progress has been made in recognizing that the main victims of climate change are those who have contributed least to climate degradation. The “Belém Action Mechanism for Just Transition” was therefore approved, which consists of an initiative to ensure that the energy transition is carried out in a socially equitable and inclusive manner, taking into account the rights and means of subsistence of workers, people of African descent, indigenous peoples and vulnerable communities. It is as if it was trying to compensate for the fact that the interests of the fossil fuel industry were practically not touched. Although the need to abandon fossil fuels was not mentioned in the final text, André Corrêa do Lago (Secretary of Climate, Energy and Environment of the Ministry of Foreign Affairs), as president of COP30, in his final address, and to appease the disappointment of many of the participants, committed to creating two roadmaps: one to “stop and reverse deforestation and the other for the transition from fossil fuels in a fair, orderly and equitable way”. Some important steps have been taken in the fight against climate change, but the absence of the leaders of the three largest greenhouse gas emitting countries (China, USA and India) does not allow us to conclude that the COP30 recommendations will be fully fulfilled. It was not an absolute success, but we should also not be so pessimistic as to say that it was a failure.
*Meteorologist Grileiros – term to designate holders of property titles, falsified using cricket excrement to appear old. Nationally Determined Contributions: they are the main instrument through which countries that have ratified the Paris Agreement communicate the commitments made with regard to combating climate change.

item.title: Germany's Strategic Awakening (II)
item.description: (Continuation of the article published on November 27th) The first effects of the crisis are visible. Emblematic is the impasse of the “Future Combat Air System (FCAS)”, a program started in 2018 to build a sixth generation jet, today on the verge of collapse. According to the newspaper Welt, the French government had demanded control of 80 percent of the project, a hypothesis considered absolutely unacceptable in Germany, to the point of leading the Ministry of Defense to consider its definitive cancellation and to show growing interest in the “Global Combat Air Programme”, developed by “BAE Systems and Leonardo” in cooperation with Mitsubishi. The fact that our Europe's original engine shows signs of failure says a lot about the true substance of European rearmament. The “ReArm Europe” plan, presented with pomp by the President of the Commission, Ursula von der Leyen, runs the risk of accentuating the inconsistencies between the continent's defense systems, as, in practice, only States with ample fiscal margin will be able to reinforce their military apparatus. European countries are rearming, but they do so unevenly and to satisfy distinctly national priorities, sometimes in conflict with each other. The German case is exemplary. In response to Paris' requests, Berlin was very clear in excluding the hypothesis of a common European debt to finance defense industries. And last March, even before formalizing the new “Große Koalition”, the Bundestag approved a monumental plan that lifts the debt brake for all military expenditure exceeding 1 percent of GDP. An unprecedented measure, which for the first time opens up the prospect of potentially unlimited rearmament. According to the most prudent estimates, Germany will have to undertake a significant annual financial effort over the next decade, representing a relevant share of its GDP. To understand the scale of the Federal Republic's ambition, it is enough to look at the list of expenses planned by officials in Berlin, which lasts for several decades and also includes part of the special fund announced by Chancellor Scholz. Among the most relevant areas are investment in ammunition, combat vehicles, naval vessels and equipment, aircraft and missiles, as well as logistical and field resources, other types of vehicles, telecommunications systems and satellite communications. Peak spending is expected between 2029 and 2030, with more than 52 billion euros per year on military equipment alone. Merz is right in stating that the Federal Republic is preparing to become the “most powerful conventional army” on the Old Continent. Less well-founded is the idea that this might automatically serve an undefined European cause. This is not about fueling useless alarmism as we are not facing the return of German militarism as we studied it in history textbooks, nor does the Berlin ruling class aspire to conquer a “place in the sun” inspired by Wilhelmina. In fact, if the occasion demands it, it is quite likely that Germany will use its military instrument in cooperation with other European countries. But it is worth remembering that the extent of this commitment will ultimately be determined exclusively by a calculation of German interests. German rearmament is there for all to see. Less clear is what Berlin's plans really are. Western pressures were important, but they are not sufficient, in themselves, to explain a phenomenon of this magnitude. You need to go deeper. There is, first of all, an economic calculation. Among the Berlin ruling class, there is a widespread conviction that rearmament can breathe new life into an industrial system in deep crisis, particularly the automobile sector. The assumption is that, in recent years, all the pillars of German prosperity have crumbled. And, unlike other Western countries, the Federal Republic is an industrial power and wants to continue to be so, as it is precisely the ability to export products with high added value that supports full employment and the welfare state. This is why, in Berlin, “reconversion” is being discussed, that is, transforming a considerable part of civilian manufacturing for military purposes, a prospect that especially attracts the defense giant Rheinmetall, desperately looking for highly qualified workers. However, it is highly unlikely that military production, even taken to the extreme, will be able to solve all of Germany's problems. There is, however, a deeper dimension. The large-scale Russian invasion of Ukraine did not create German rearmament, but only accelerated it until it became irreversible. In fact, the idea that Germany should once again consider using its military instrument had been cultivated in Berlin strategic circles for more than a decade. In May 2010, Federal President Horst Köhler stated, in a radio interview, that the Germans should prepare themselves “to use force in defense of their interests”. These words caused such a scandal that they forced him to resign. But Köhler did nothing more than make public, perhaps with excessive frankness, what was being discussed behind the scenes. It was no coincidence that, just two years later, two of Berlin's most influential think tanks the “Stiftung Wissenschaft und Politik” and the “German Marshall Fund” launched the project “New Power, New Responsibility: Elements of a German foreign and security policy for a changing world” in October 2013. The final report, with more than 50 pages, was perfectly aligned with Köhler's vision that “German citizens lived in an era of unprecedented security. But traditional threats such as war, nuclear proliferation and terrorism continue to exist. Germany is existentially dependent on exchange with other societies, and the vulnerability of neighbors and allies also affects its own security. Its protection is therefore in its interests, when and where necessary.” Participants included security experts, representatives of the arms industry, officials from the Ministries of Defense and Foreign Affairs, and members of the Bundestag. This is why, between 2016 and 2018, the Bundeswehr formally changed its main mission, moving from global crisis management to territorial defense. This revolution remained for years only on paper, but in practice it made possible the rearmament announced by Scholz in 2022. In a sense, the speech about the Zeitenwende (historical turning point) had been ready for a long time and was just waiting to be pronounced. The turning point concerned urgency, not the concept. In three years, a minority idea became common sense, a result that is mainly due to the initiative of the ruling class, committed to a total effort to reintroduce a military ethos into the fabric of civil society. The real revolution is taking place in the mind of the average German, for whom war is no longer unthinkable. Voices calling for peace without weapons, once dominant, have been progressively excluded from public debate. Emblematic is the case of the book by young journalist Ole Nymoen, “Warum ich niemals für mein Land kämpfen würde (Why I would never fight for my country)” published on March 11, 2025. At the time of publication it caused controversy, but its theses were never truly taken seriously. In the Bundestag, only Die Linke remains openly pacifist, while the AfD and traditional parties find an unprecedented point of agreement. Defense Minister Boris Pistorius, currently the most popular politician in the country, does not miss an opportunity to assert that the Bundeswehr must once again be "capable of fighting" (kriegstüchtig) and has not ruled out a war between NATO and Russia by 2029. And the population follows, as more than two thirds of Germans say they support doubling defense spending by 2032. We are at the center of a decade that, in all probability, will lead to the end of the complex of historical guilt that has weighed on Germans for the last eighty years. The past will not be erased or forgotten, but it will gradually stop limiting Berlin's room for maneuver. Thus ends, in part, what the British historian Alec Ryrie defined as the “era of Hitler”, that is, the long post-war period in which Adolf Hitler was “the most powerful and unifying figure”, erected as an absolute negative in the moral canon of nations and individuals. A new Germany is emerging on the horizon, and its contours remain largely undefined. The only certainty is that it will transform Europe.

item.title: Lessons from the Hong Kong tragedy
item.description: The devastating fire at Hung Fook Court in Tai Po, Hong Kong, broke out in seven or eight buildings. Maintenance work was taking place in these buildings and the contractors used highly flammable expansive foam to seal windows and the scaffolding used was made of bamboo, which allowed the fire to spread quickly after it started in one of the buildings. Strong winds and dry weather caused the flames to intensify, which subsequently affected the entire housing block. The fire alarms did not go off, contributing to the tragedy. Around 48 hours after the accident, the Hong Kong Government had practically extinguished the fire. With the help of the Central Government, which sent substantial resources to Hong Kong, and numerous companies that donated money and supplies, the needs were met, allowing the victims to have temporary respite. At the time of writing this article, the Hong Kong Government has just announced that there have been 146 deaths, 79 injured and 40 missing. Among the dead is a heroic firefighter who died fighting the flames. Before we continue our analysis, let us observe a minute of silence for those who lost their lives and pray for the survivors, hoping that they can soon overcome their difficulties. We also express our highest respect to all the workers and volunteers who participated in the rescue operations, praising their courage and dedication in the face of adversity. In addition to caring for the victims, the Hong Kong Government also quickly sought to identify those responsible for the accident. For example, the person responsible for maintaining the Hung Fook Court was arrested and is suspected of involuntary manslaughter. The Independent Commission Against Corruption (ICAC) also ordered the arrest of individuals suspected of corruption. The Hong Kong Government immediately carried out surprise inspections of all protective nets used in building maintenance to ensure they met fire safety standards. The insurers working with the building maintenance companies also publicly stated that they had activated emergency mechanisms and would provide adequate compensation in accordance with the contracts concluded. In Hong Kong, some people suggested that maintenance companies should use metal scaffolding instead of bamboo scaffolding in the future. How will the victims deal with the consequences of this disaster? Firstly, the injured must receive immediate treatment. Secondly, they should immediately contact the families to let them know they are safe. We saw many people on television worried about their families, crying and waiting for news. Sending them a message to reassure them is essential. Thirdly, they will have to solve the accommodation problem. If they have another place to live or if they can stay with family or friends, they will need to continue these steps. It is not known when they will be able to return home. If they have no solution, they will have to join the Hong Kong Government's temporary accommodation program. Fourth, assuming the government inspection finds the house is still habitable, should the owners renovate it? Hung Fook Court opened in 1983, more than 40 years ago, and repair work had already begun. This devastating fire accelerated the devaluation of the property. Homeowners should consider whether it is worth making large investments in renovation, given the future value of the homes and the likelihood of them being sold successfully. In addition to the different reactions of the Hong Kong Government, the public and the victims, this devastating accident has, in fact, raised other issues that concern society. First, Hong Kong is by nature a city with a high cost of living. A worker who manages to buy a house with the salary he earns during his working life achieves a significant feat. After two or three decades of paying the mortgage, the building has become worn out and needs major work. At that point, owners need to make large investments in maintenance, making the house and the problems it raises seem like a bottomless pit, a black hole impossible to fill. The relationship between homeowners and their homes is reminiscent of the title of a television series – “property slaves.” Second, following this rare accident, contractors will be more careful about the materials they use. Insurers will also be more careful when entering into contracts with maintenance companies and will impose more stringent requirements. This means that insurance premiums may increase. Homeowners who purchased home and fire insurance may also see their premiums change. All of these factors will fall on home owners, meaning they will bear more expenses. For owners who are still working, this situation is compounded by additional charges. What about retired owners? They may have set up a fund for maintenance before retirement, but with their financial situation after retirement, they may no longer be able to cover these expenses. This should be an issue for all homeowners who were not directly affected by the fire and potential homebuyers to consider. Although properties in Hong Kong are valuable, they also give rise to many problems. This devastating accident brought new perspectives to the Hong Kong Government, society, victims and potential homebuyers. Let us hope that these new ideas benefit Hong Kong society and prevent similar tragedies. Legal Consultant of the Association for the Promotion of Jazz in Macau Associate Professor at the Faculty of Management Sciences of the Macau Polytechnic University

item.title: Celebrations pleased some fascists
item.description: More than 50 years ago, the Portuguese people, including the “snitches” of PIDE/DGS, took to the streets to celebrate the greatest gift a people can have: freedom. A military coup had ended a political dictatorship of more than 40 years. The military of the Armed Forces Movement (MFA) had managed to overthrow an oppressive regime that spent years arresting and deporting those who defended freedom, democracy, socialism and communism. The times following the military coup were turbulent because we soon realized that these soldiers also had their political options and were also beginning to play into the hands of this or that political party. Mário Soares and Álvaro Cunhal returned from exile and on the first May 1st the party was thunderous and with a popular union never seen before. As time went by, we saw that the divergences between the MFA military, supported by certain parties, bordered on radicalism. On September 28, 1974, we witnessed an attempted coup d'état carried out by conservative sectors, led by the President of the Republic, General António de Spínola and where the so-called “silent majority” prevailed at the time, which aimed to halt the democratic process, but, essentially, control decisions on decolonization. The left-wing sector of the MFA managed to ban a demonstration in support of Spínola and we remember that barricades were placed at the entrances to Lisbon in order to prevent the entry of Spínola's supporters. As a result, several organizers of the demonstration were arrested, General Spínola resigned as President of the Republic and the event marked the defeat of the attempt to turn to the right and the strengthening of the MFA's control over the revolutionary process. First important note: never in more than 50 years of democracy have left-wing democrats celebrated the victory of September 28, 1974. On March 11, 1975, we personally witnessed another attempted coup d'état, this time, commanded by General António de Spínola against the government of the time supported by the left-wing MFA military. The attempt began with the bombing of the Light Artillery Regiment No. 1 (RAL 1) and a soldier who was lying in one of the barracks was killed. The RTP archives must contain images of the piercing of the roof and the blood on the bed and floor of the barracks. RAL 1 was surrounded by paratroopers, assigned to Spínola, and negotiations lasted almost the entire day. The attempt would fail due to the lack of popular support for Spínola and due to the resistance that was registered by the RAL 1 military and many people. The failure of the coup attempt would lead to Spínola's flight to Spain and then to Brazil. Second important note: left-wing democrats in more than 50 years of democracy have never celebrated victory over the attempt to interrupt the revolutionary process. The summer that followed was very “hot” with several disputes within the MFA and with right-wing parties intensifying their confrontation with the Communist Party and other radical left parties. Everything would end on November 25, 1975. On that day, the left-wing MFA military occupied RTP and Captain Duran Clemente, while speaking directly at the public television studios, was interrupted from one moment to the next and the broadcast began to be directed from the studios in Porto. Simultaneously at the Military Police barracks, the soldiers on duty there commanded by Major Tomé found themselves confronted by military commandos from the right wing of the MFA, commanded by Captain Jaime Neves and Major Ramalho Eanes. The shooting was a reality. Two military commandos and others from the Military Police died. At the Belém Palace, where the President of the Republic, General Costa Gomes, resided, calls were made for the arrest of the 25th of April strategist, Otelo Saraiva de Carvalho, and the illegalization of the Communist Party. At the end of the afternoon, with the Commando troops controlling all operations in their favor, an MFA meeting was held where the moderate wing, led by Major Melo Antunes, managed to ensure that Otelo was not arrested and that the Communist Party remained a legal party at the service of democracy. The 25th of November, a political dispute, but essentially between military personnel, was immediately announced as a “heroic” restoration of the democratic state. Third important note: never in more than 50 years of democracy have right-wing political forces remembered to officially celebrate November 25, 1975. Last week, we found that the 25th of November was officially celebrated with pomp and circumstance and, obviously, with the support of right-wing and extreme-right political forces, with the disagreement of the Socialist Party and other left-wing political parties and, aggravatingly, the date was celebrated in the Assembly of the Republic with the presence of President Marcelo Rebelo de Sousa. The truth is that we witnessed the positions of individuals defending fascist and neo-Nazi policies, stating that the celebrations of November 25th “were much more important than those of April 25th”. We no longer have any doubts that the political system in Portugal is changing. A dangerous change. A change in which racists, xenophobes and neo-Nazis advance proposals in Parliament that receive the support of the elected Montenegro Government, which announces itself as democratic. No, my friends. We must realize that the political change we are witnessing could end in a dictatorship disguised as democracy, where prisons and a lack of press freedom will be a reality.

item.title: AMAGAO | “Meet You There” features works by Alexandre Marreiros and Nyoman Suarnata
item.description: Architect and artist Alexandre Marreiros is back at exhibitions, but this time he is not alone. In “Meet You There”, opened today at the AMAGAO gallery, Marreiros joins his friend Nyoman Suarnata for an exhibition that reflects “territories of adjustable perception”, with concepts shaped by “collaboration, dialogue and imagination” The AMAGAO gallery, a project by Lina Ramadas and Vítor Hugo Marreiros, hosts a new exhibition today. “Meet You There” begins to receive its first visitors at 6:30 pm, featuring works by two artists who decided to join forces: Alexandre Marreiros, who usually wanders between arts and architecture, and Nyoman Suarnata. In the curatorial text about this exhibition, it is stated that “Meet You There” is not just “a point on the map”, but rather “a conceptual territory shaped by collaboration, dialogue and imagination”, where the two artists “transform canvas and paper into a shared space where perception is fluid and the narrative pulses like a living organism”. This “creative encounter” brings a new “place where visual language becomes an instrument of investigation”, with works with “overlapping compositions, fragmented symbols and constantly shifting perspectives”, where “artists build a territory that resists fixed meaning”. And what elements live in this new territory full of concepts and conceptions? “Social, personal and environmental concerns”, which then “metamorphose into characters, symbols and even superheroes”. "These are not figures that save, but that reveal. They are incarnations of urgency, empathy and resistance, challenging the viewer to reflect: what does it mean to care? Imagine? Act?", the same text asks. This exhibition invites you “to participate in a space where art is not static, but generative; where dialogue is not linear, but stratified; and where imagination is a form of engagement and participation”. Studio work Speaking to HM about the exhibition, Alexandre Marreiros talks about an exhibition created by two friends, with much of the work carried out in Macau, together, in a permanent collaboration. This was due to “several trips that Nyoman made to Macau, namely to my studio, where he was free to choose any of my works”. "There was always an interesting construction, a long process, first for Nyoman to free himself and choose a work of mine without limitations. After a day of work I responded to his interventions. At first it was a curious thing, because he had great respect and almost didn't touch the parts he had already painted and I didn't touch his things either, but we felt that there was a kind of limit, something we didn't want. There was a very interesting exercise in liberation, in which I opened the doors of my studio, I gave him the works that He had to be able to choose and intervene in them, and then I would respond.” Thus, 34 works emerged in around two years of joint work, in which the artistic skills of both came into contact. "If we look back, we see that I always have a graphic resource and also the word in my works. Nyoman also has that register, something perhaps more handwritten, and I had other techniques, be it screen printing, lithography or drawing, I used them a lot to transport the word to my works." Alexandre Marreiros assumes that “in some way, there is always a character” in his works, namely “poets and philosophers”, more specifically “there is always a predominant character in my work, which is Luís de Camões”; while Nyoman “has a universe of characters that can be assimilated, or not, in a critical way, or that can be considered superheroes or a human being with supernatural powers”. “Meet You There” is, therefore, the result of a permanent collaboration, in which one artist worked on the other’s works in their absence, in which there were “few opportunities, perhaps 10 or 20 percent, in which we could both participate directly in the work”. “It's something you feel in the work, which is honest, in the sense that there is a universe of communion, universality and trust, of two very different people who meet, respect and admire each other”, said Marreiros. Contemporary themes In these works there is satire “of the times in which we live”, namely “in a series of works, the first, and which are very much the representation of what Nyoman sees in Macau”. There is then another series “with his superheroes and mine, which are always the writers, philosophers and human beings who, in some way, left their mark on this passage that is life”. There are also other works “a little more linked to Macau, namely to the world of casinos”. “I actively and directly participate in this Macau identity and industry and, therefore, it is natural that this universe appears in my work and there are interventions and reinterpretations by Nyoman.” Macau has always been, for the two artists, “a meeting and work point”, with this project being “a liberation” for Alexandre Marreiros, in the sense that he opened the door of his studio to Nyoman's interventions. It is “an exhibition that talks about globalization, relationships of trust, cultural, artistic and intellectual differences that can coexist in the same territory”. There are satirical messages “that reveal some concerns of the two artists in the context in which they live and in the context in which they operate globally”. “Meet You There” is, for Alexandre Marreiros, “an exposure of our time and context, and revealing that differences can coexist and create beautiful dialogues and narratives, which are also different”.

item.title: Festival of short films and animations to see in the Capitol
item.description: Another edition of the Macau International Short Film Festival has been taking place since Tuesday, promoted by Creative Macau. The sessions take place daily at the Capitol Theater, in the center of Macau, and the awards for the best films, in different categories, will be awarded on the 12th of this month. Starting at 8:30 pm, this Wednesday, the winning films for “Best Film of the Festival”, “Best Fiction”, “Best Documentary” and “Best Animation” will be announced. Today's sessions start at 5pm and feature animated films, namely “Tape”, by Wing Ki Hui; “Fox Box”, by Ao Ka Meng and Wu Hua Lin, from Macau; and “GARU Y PONKI”, by Cristhian Jallier, from Colombia. The film “Granny Pirate3: Typhoon Again”, by Vitty Ho, is also shown in Macau. In this film, a pirate grandmother fights a typhoon to invade the market, but only returns with basic ingredients. While he despairs, the grandson arrives with the “Forbidden Temptation”, a cup of instant noodles, which leads to a warm and surprising surrender on a wild night, describes the film's synopsis. Vitty Ho is a visual artist who graduated in Taiwan with a scholarship from the Macau Cultural Institute, having completed a master's degree at the Graduate Institute of Creative Video and Digital Media Industry. She works as a freelance visual designer for theater and video production and previously worked as a tutor in several secondary schools in Macau. Fictional names The festival's program for today, in the fiction category, also features more international titles, namely “Prosto skaji privet / Just Say Hi”, by Olga Smelova, from Russia; “Yo Yo”, by Mohamadreza Mayghani, a joint production between Iran and France; “GOTERAS / Frip”, by Vincente Gónzalez, from Colombia; and also “Plac Wolnosci 4 / Story From Liberty Street”, by Kacper Wiacek, from Poland. This first round of short films begins to be presented to the public at 7:30 pm, followed by a second round of films at 8:45 pm. In this second round, Portuguese-language films stand out, such as “Ausente”, by Pedro Nogueira; or “Coração de Mar”, by Neto Borges and Larissa Malty, from Brazil and Portugal. Pedro Hasrouny, also from Portugal, signs the project “Uma Mãe Vai à Praia”. On Friday, the program starts at 5pm with animated films, also in Portuguese, namely “Três Vírgula Catorze”, by Joana Nogueira and Patrícia Rodrigues.

item.title: SCM Hostel | Mariana Rocha's look at bamboo and local architecture
item.description: A new exhibition opens next Monday, the 8th, at Albergue da Santa Casa da Misericórdia. This is “No Limiar da Memória”, by Mariana Maia Rocha, a project with ingredients from Macau’s memory and architecture, including bamboo construction, in which the artist presents herself as a “diasporic observer”. It is called “On the Threshold of Memory” and presents itself as an “exhibition that confronts the architecture of transience in the material and spiritual landscape of Macau”. This new exhibition, which will open next Monday, the 8th, at Albergue da Santa Casa da Misericórdia (SCM), starting at 6:30 pm, is the result of a resident project by Mariana Maia Rocha, a Portuguese artist. According to a note from Albergue SCM, Mariana uses here “her position as a diasporic observer and the experience of an immersive residence in Asian territory to investigate the paradoxical status of bamboo”, as a “pillar of local vernacular construction”. This is in the sense that bamboo “transitions from the utilitarian and profane to the domain of cultural heritage and the sacred, given its imminent replacement by iron and concrete”. Also according to the same note, this exhibition is relevant for “its critical analysis of accelerated urban transformations and the impact of globalization on local identity, a scenario of particular resonance in Macau”. Thus, it becomes a “juxtaposition of symbolic materialities that underline the Portuguese-Chinese duality”, in which dust, transfigured into coal, graphite and ash of local origin, “functions as the ‘index’ of mortality, the fundamental substance of the universal ‘memento mori’”. In turn, “votive wax, common to Taoist and Catholic rituals, is used to mold ex-votos from the artist's shoes, configuring a procedural line that metaphorizes the personal journey and the vulnerability of the body”. Mariana Maia Rocha also presents, in this project, an “ephemeral urban intervention with latex recording the texture of the Portuguese sidewalk”. “This tactile “second skin” “works as a memory device, alluding to the scaffolding protection networks and the disappearing Portuguese legacy, creating a physical record of the cultural border and the negotiation of urban space”, he explains. Dialogues and contexts Taking into account the artist's readings on these elements so linked to Macau's identity, “No Limiar da Memória” can be described as an attempt to create “a powerful dialogue about memory, mortality and the ephemeral structures that we build”. Here, “the artist’s practice navigates the tension between the permanent and the fleeting, cultural identity and the inevitability of disintegration in a territory of convergence and loss, echoing the complexities of a rapidly changing place.” Mariana Maia Rocha is a visual artist and researcher whose interdisciplinary practice is part of the intersection between the body, memory and territory. His work, which predominantly integrates drawing, photoperformance and installation, addresses the conceptual and material boundaries of presence and erasure in the contemporary archive. The artist graduated from the Faculty of Fine Arts of the University of Porto, where she completed her master's degree in Fine Arts, receiving a scholarship from the Calouste Gulbenkian Foundation, namely in 2023/2024, when she won the “Gulbenkian New Talents” scholarship. Still in the academic area, this year he won a doctoral scholarship to continue studies abroad. In 2023, the artist participated in the “Mirror Identity Drawings” (MIDD) project, signed by the UNESCO Charter. The international dimension of his practice has materialized, this year, through a program of artistic residencies, in São Tomé and Príncipe, in the context of the XI Bienal de São Tomé; and now in Macau, within the scope of the international program “Territories without Borders” (2025–2026), promoted by the Fundação Bienal de Arte de Cerveira. Since 2018, his work has been presented in solo and collective exhibitions at leading institutions, including the Museu Nacional de Arte Contemporânea do Chiado (MNAC) (Lisbon), Fundação Júlio Resende (Porto), Palácio Vila Flor (Guimarães) and Galeria Kubik (Porto), among others. He has already received dozens of distinctions for his work.

item.title: Book | “Receita di Casa” by Antonieta Manhão awarded in Saudi Arabia
item.description: Macanese chef Antonieta Manhão, better known as “Chef Neta”, has just seen her work honored with two awards in Saudi Arabia. More specifically, the book “Receita di Casa” won two awards in the international competition “Gourmand Awards Food Culture”, in the Gourmet categories and in the group of trilingual publications, Portuguese, Chinese and English, which were awarded in Riyadh. This is a book edited by Dorris Lei, from Co-Write Limited, translated by Adelaide Ferreira. Of note is the more than 1,200 works sent to this competition, with six being selected for the final of the group of recipe publications, with the aim of distinguishing “The Best Cookbooks in The World”. At the awards ceremony, 96 countries were represented. “Receita di Casa” was launched in January this year and features 19 recipes for typical Macanese dishes, namely the famous Minchi, Capela or Sopa Lacassá, among many others. “Neta” Manhão is also a professor of Macanese cuisine at the Macau Tourism University.

item.title: Floods | DSAMA publishes Tide Table for 2026
item.description: The Directorate of Services for Maritime and Water Affairs (DSAMA) has just released the Tide Table for next year, stating, in a statement, that the “pioneering introduction of hourly tide height data” is being made, which can help combat floods. In this way, “the prediction of the tide height at each hour is added, in addition to the data on the height of high tides and low tides each day, allowing the maritime sector and the general public to access in a more practical way the predictions of hourly variations in tides”. Tidal data collection began in 1925, and Macau's annual tide tables have been produced since 1960. Tide predictions are obtained from the analysis of tide level data, measured and permanently recorded at the Porto Interior Tide Station. Tide forecast data is made available in real time to meteorological services for reference, allowing the calculation of tidal heights resulting from the combination of astronomical tides and the effects of “Stormsurge”.

item.title: DSAT | Survey reveals that almost half of trips are made on foot
item.description: A study carried out by the Directorate of Services for Traffic Affairs (DSAT), relating to 2024, revealed that, among the different modes of travel, walking continues to record the highest proportion, with around 46.5 percent, similar to the 2019 record. However, the proportion falls by 3.2 percent compared to 2009. It is important to note that the survey is carried out every five years. The second most used means of movement in the city is once again the public bus, despite a drop of one percentage point to 20.9 percent last year. Regarding the use of private passenger cars, DSAT reported a slight increase of 0.8 percent between 2024 and 2019, for a total of 15.5 percent. The percentage varies greatly depending on the area of ​​residence, with Coloane, naturally, being the most suitable area for traveling by car or motorcycle. The survey also reveals that motorcycle travel fell slightly between 2019 and last year, with 11.3 percent of the population being the preferred transport.

item.title: IAM | Dogs appear dead again in Coloane
item.description: An internet user shared photographs of three dead dogs on Facebook and reported the presence of IAM employees carelessly spreading rat poison. The IAM says that autopsies revealed systemic hemorrhagic lesions and that death from poisoning is “extremely low”. The case was referred to the police It happened again. On Wednesday, photographs of dead dogs were published on Facebook. The author, who suspected death by poisoning, says he saw employees from the Institute for Municipal Affairs (IAM) and a company hired by the public entity spreading rat poison in an area, in Coloane, where a dead dog was found. According to the publication, the internet user approached IAM and cleaning company employees criticizing the method of applying the poison in violation of established guidelines, which would be exposed on the side of the road, within reach of people and domestic animals. In response, the complainant states that he was told that everything was fine, and they continued to deposit the poison despite the citizen's protests. On Wednesday night, the IAM issued a statement addressing the issue, stating that it had received “successive reports from citizens about the discovery of three dog corpses in three adjacent locations in Coloane”, starting last Saturday. Stating that it is “highly attentive to the incident”, the IAM indicates that it immediately deployed personnel to monitor the cases in the locations in question. "After the autopsy of the corpses and respective analysis, it was found that the three dogs in question had systemic hemorrhagic lesions. The Institute has already reported the case to the police, awaiting further investigation." Carbon paper Regarding the suspicion of poison ingestion by dogs, the IAM highlighted that the product currently used “contains a bitter agent, specifically designed for rats due to their lack of vomiting reflex”. "For animals with a vomiting system, including cats and dogs, accidental ingestion causes a vomiting reaction, making swallowing difficult. Therefore, the probability of poisoning through accidental ingestion is extremely low. Furthermore, the dose of bait placed by IAM workers each time is specifically calculated for the small size of rats," added the public entity. In the Facebook post, the internet user published a photograph where you can see a pile of reddish colored sprinkles. The institute led by Chao Wai Ieng also indicated that the poison is placed in fixed and locked boxes, or in rat holes, remaining hidden and without easy contact by people or animals. A statement completely contradictory to the report of the internet user who reported the situation. At the beginning of May, a similar case also occurred in Taipa with three dead dogs and similar suspicions. At the time, the IAM issued a statement similar to the one released on Wednesday night.

item.title: HIV | Association warns of increasing trends
item.description: Kelvin Lei, project supervisor at the Macao AIDS Care Association, warns of the complexity of the greater number of HIV cases in the non-resident population and regrets that the stigma surrounding the virus and the disease is still a reality in the territory The Macao AIDS Care Association speaks of a scenario of complexity given the growing number of new HIV cases among non-residents. In an interview with HM, Kelvin Lei, the association's project supervisor, describes that “the trend observed among non-residents is complex and reflects structural factors, and not just individual behavior”. These factors are “Macau’s status as an international hub, which means a constant flow of people, including visitors, immigrant workers and students from around the world”, who “may have different attitudes towards high-risk sexual behavior due to their cultural diversity and academic background”. For Kelvin Lei, “greater attention to testing and detecting cases among non-residents can lead to more diagnoses”, and “barriers [in access] to services” persist, particularly due to “linguistic differences, limited knowledge of local health rights, concerns about confidentiality or work schedules that conflict with opening hours”. “The fear of stigma or job loss” still remains, scenarios that can be “a significant impediment to seeking tests or health care”. There are also “socio-economic factors” that explain the growth in cases. Data from the Health Services in November speak of a growing trend in cases: between January and September this year, 28 new cases of HIV infection were registered, 14 of which were among residents and 14 among non-residents. Last year, there was no reference to non-residents being infected. In comparison, between January and September last year, nine cases had been confirmed among residents, meaning that throughout this year there has been a 55.6 percent increase in new cases detected. Important role The conversation with Kelvin Lei arose regarding the holding, this weekend, of the 8th Forum on AIDS in Beijing, Hong Kong, Macau and Taiwan, taking place in Lisbon Macau, in Cotai. In 2016, Macau had organized another edition of this event. For Kelvin Lei, the repetition of Macau as a host location “has a profound meaning” for the association, as it “reaffirms the active and committed role” of the territory “as a vital bridge in the regional partnership between Beijing, Hong Kong and Taiwan in the fight against HIV/AIDS”. “Although Macau’s prevalence [of new cases] remains relatively low, we face distinct challenges, including a mobile population and the need for sustained and targeted prevention,” he said. “The misconception that HIV only affects specific groups, such as men who have sex with men, as is the case globally” also persists in the territory. This is a “harmful idea, because it creates a false sense of security in other populations and worsens stigma”. Focus on the individual Regarding stigma, Kelvin Lei draws attention to the fact that, “in compact communities like Macau and Hong Kong”, there is “a fear of social disclosure within close-knit networks”. It is up to the Executive to incorporate another type of discourse into its policies, he suggested. "We recognize and appreciate the SAR Government's commitment and resource allocation to prevention and treatment, with the clinical infrastructure providing essential antiretroviral therapy. The doctor-patient ratio in this specific area is managed. The discourse has progressively shifted towards a scientific and public health framework. However, the next frontier is to truly integrate the fight against stigma into official discourse and systemic practice." The supervisor speaks of the need for public defense of the “U=U” concept, that is, “undetectable – non-transmissible”, in addition to the need to “promote person-centered care that looks at the individual, and not just the virus”. Kelvin Lei also advises “promoting the standardization of tests for everyone and guaranteeing non-discriminatory policies in all contexts”. Therefore, holding the Forum this weekend brings a dialogue “with representatives from all regions, including the Government, which is a positive step towards aligning our scientific capabilities, with the necessary social support, to end the epidemic”. It is also intended to analyze “innovative strategies, such as long-term prevention and artificial intelligence applications that we are discussing, and a spirit of solidarity”. The AIDS Care Association in Macau sees itself as “one of the main associations in HIV prevention in Macau”, facing “non-medical challenges”, such as “internalized and social stigma”, which “can lead to profound loneliness and mental health problems”. It is also necessary to “guarantee continuity of care”, with “holistic needs” on the part of patients, such as medication, “psychological counseling, support to reveal the condition to family or employers and, sometimes, nutritional or financial assistance”. This association therefore provides a series of support in this regard.

item.title: Law | Macau lawyers with strengthened powers in the interior
item.description: Since yesterday, lawyers from Macau, Hong Kong and Taiwan have been able to represent clients in more types of civil litigation in the Interior, according to an announcement from the Ministry of Justice, cited by the newspaper Ou Mun. The measure only applies to local lawyers recognized by Interior. With the changes, local lawyers have access to 299 types of civil rights cases, in areas such as trade, maritime disputes, personality rights or industrial rights protection cases. However, the intervention of local lawyers is only authorized if it is done on behalf of parties from Macau, Hong Kong or Taiwan involved in these processes. The data cited by the publication indicates that there are currently around 760 lawyers from Hong Kong, Macau and Taiwan who have been granted authorization to work in the Interior. More than 630 lawyers from Hong Kong and Macau also received the certificate to practice in the Greater Bay Area. Macau lawyers can practice on the other side of the border if they speak the language, have obtained a degree in law in the Interior or if they have a certification recognizing their qualifications.

item.title: Satellite casinos | Initiative promoted to mitigate impact of closure
item.description: The ZAPE Industrial and Commercial Association of Macau and around 250 businesses invested 3 million patacas in online training to promote this area of ​​the city on social media Around 250 NAPE and ZAPE businesses joined together in an initiative led by the ZAPE Industrial and Commercial Association of Macau to mitigate the economic impact in the areas of the closure of several satellite casinos. According to Macau Business magazine, the initiative involves an investment of 3 million patacas. The objective is to transform the area into an attractive place to take photos and post on social media, to bring a new type of tourist to the area and create a more consumer-oriented model. The plan is seen as an alternative path for the economy in that area, after the forced closure of several satellite casinos that thrived in those parts of the city for years. Also to make commerce in the area more competitive, support was distributed for the development of advertising activities for online and on-site commercial spaces. Regarding the initiative, Wu Tat Chong, president of the ZAPE Industrial and Commercial Association of Macau, explained that it is motivated “by changes in the market and in people's consumption habits that have caused businesses in ZAPE and NAPE to face new challenges, such as a fluctuating number of customers”. The official also indicated that due to the new reality, “competition has become more intense” which has meant that many businesses in those locations “are fighting for their survival”. Support from outside The campaign promoted by the ZAPE Industrial and Commercial Association of Macau also seeks to draw attention to the areas, with online campaigns, then encouraging physical experiences. In a first phase, participating stores now receive training on how to explore online promotion platforms. Additionally, the campaign allows for subsidy-based promotions and specific marketing schemes to increase companies' visibility. In addition to participants from the territory, the initiative also involves the involvement of takeaway delivery platforms in Hong Kong. In view of the expected loss of business in those areas, imposed by deputies following a proposal from the Government, the Executive has tried to present actions to take people to those locations. One of the anticipated events is the organization of a Christmas Festival, organized as a complement to the Iluminar Macau Festival, between December and the beginning of next year.

item.title: Social housing | Man loses apartment for having property in China
item.description: A candidate for social housing, with two daughters, lost his right to the apartment because he had a property in the interior of China that was not declared, initially, to the Housing Institute (IH). This situation arises in a ruling by the Court of Second Instance (TSI), released yesterday, regarding an appeal presented by the man, when he lost the right to this Government housing. The case dates back to 2011, when the lease contract with IH was signed, but in 2022, during its review, the man added to the declaration, for the first time, that he owned a property in the country valued at more than 350 thousand renminbi. The IH therefore understood that the candidate no longer had the conditions to live in a social house, and the refund of the residence allowance received between May and July 2011, in the total value of 4,800 patacas, was also required. The man appealed the decision to the Administrative Court and then to the TSI, but this court understood that “the decision to terminate the contract in order to balance the distribution of resources and avoid harm to private interests is not manifestly unreasonable”.

item.title: ZELENSKY VS ZELENSKY
item.description:
10/27/22 A Ukrainian pensioner, with the same name as the president, blames Zelensky for the prolongation of the conflict that destroyed his village. Zelensky, the villager, who never left his land, is now mortified because his favorite gravedigger died in the bomber. This Zelensky, a villager, represents half the world that recriminates the other Zelensky, the villain, for not wanting to negotiate with Putin. Negotiate what? The invader enters our house, covers his wife and daughter (cf. recent UN report on the rapes in Ukraine, in this “special operation”), an act that forced us to watch, and then we say to him: hi there, we are for peace, but we have to negotiate: you still haven't said what name you want to give the children! A peace that is not dignified is nothing more than a cessation of rights. As serious as the Russophobia that Putin inflicts on his people.
10/28/22 At a lunch with several guests, I heard a friend, who declared herself a spiritualist, explaining the particularities of her belief, in a calm and balanced way, I would even say, without a hint of “irrationalism”. He spoke at length and serenely, devoid of any fanatical proselytism. “Here is someone whose belief has brought thoughtfulness!” I thought, a rare alliance. However, at a certain moment a sentence comes out that horrifies me. He says, “there is no chance, nothing happens by chance!”, and I glimpse the voracious maws of holism. Because holism has a pathological aspect, like all good things, a shadow side. Two examples: in Hinduism there is less sensitivity to existential dramas, if that child suffers in this life this is just an expression of rigorous karmic symmetry, an effect of the acts he committed in his previous life. In Africa, it is not accepted that death could have been accidental, and many women are accused by the family of the deceased of having caused the death of their husband, in an act of manifest dementia, and, in the blatant majority of cases, a huge injustice for the wife — madness that spreads and infiltrates the social fabric. Buddhism introduced Compassion and Christianity introduced Caritas, trying to break with this logic, but in many other beliefs and religions the cage of causalities prevails over sensitivity to experience, the need to respond to the now. It is a tremendous logic that transforms the world into a Platonic stage, where we are nothing more than the shadows of something — an inextricable law -, in a determinism that calcifies all singularities, but that strangely fascinates many. The conquest of modernity was anchored in the conquest of chance and randomness, removing the incidences of a life from this fierce determinism that enclosed the world in a web. When the Renaissance freed the body from the influence of the stars, at that moment sexuality was relieved of guilt and individualism and its volition were able to emerge. There is an unequivocal moral implication in the phrase “there is no such thing as chance, nothing happens by chance!”, which should function as a key to self-knowledge and self-judgment, however, this phrase is usually used to seek a reason for things outside of us, in others. It's an alibi. Today there is a holistic temptation in the world, just as there was a satanic temptation in the Middle Ages, without much reflection on its consequences. Because it's not enough to want to connect everything in a resonant chain of affection. Even for the most unexpected: affection itself can kill. I realize, thanks to that cultured, balanced, intelligent woman, that “the fight” took place at the beginning of this century. One of the great mistakes of the 20th century was the false dichotomy between “rationalism and irrationalism”, a debate that extended to all fields, including art. First, rationality (the positive side of reason) was confused with rationalism (the pathological aspect of reason), and articulated in this lack of discernment, irrationalism was confused with freedom.
